abstract.para: This document introduces the key concepts of Information Sharing Planning, provides a reference guide to the Channels Web application, and shows how to apply the ISP Method with Channels to systematically build and analyze information sharing plans. A lexicon of ISP terms and the complete list of detectable ISP issues can be found in the Appendix.

section.title: Why Plan the Sharing of Information?
section.para: Most organizations now operate in complex "ecosystems" where they depend on each other for information critical to their missions. It is common wisdom that getting the right information at the right time is essential to achieving mission success. This is even more so in a connected world where opportunities can be fleeting and risks can spread not only quickly but far and wide.

Yet most organizations do not plan how they should share information within and across organizational boundaries. It is something of a paradox that while they will plan their finances or model their business processes to achieve greater efficiency, they will rarely define how they need to communicate to better prevent, respond or recover from crises.

Failure to plan how information should flow can cost lives, money, reputation. During a crisis, information will not spontaneously flow as needed and maintaining contact lists is clearly not enough. Organizations must prepare and create actionable information sharing procedures. Information sharing can and should be planned not only to be prepared but also to capture, retain and disseminate communication best practices.

para.emphasis: Information Sharing Planning (ISP) models, analyzes and deploys knowledge of how organizations need to share information to mitigate systemic risks and seize opportunities from anticipated events.

section.para: ISP provides a framework and method for designing and improving the information sharing procedures required by networked organizations to achieve their missions.

section.title: Why Use Channels to Plan Information Sharing?
section.para: Planners use Channels, a Web application, to jointly build information sharing plans (IS plans). Planning information sharing is done ahead of anticipated events. Channels is not meant for managing the actual sharing of information during a crisis.
When building IS plans using Channels, planners clarify and uncover:

listitem.para: who needs what information, why, and when
who has or can produce needed information, how, and when
what information should flow, when, and how
flaws in information sharing practices
how people, systems, and organizations should be networked
the consequences of not sharing according to plan
where shared information originally comes from and ultimately ends up

section.para:
Building an IS plan in Channels can be divided into
modeling information sharing practices (IS practices)
profiling the environment (organizations, people, and places) the IS practices apply to

When modeling IS practices, planners describe what kind of people and systems (or agents) are to be assigned to planned tasks. More importantly, planners describe what information would be acquired by the execution of a task and then shared with others who need it to carry out their own tasks. A model of IS would normally not identify task assignees by name, but rather specify them by their roles, qualifications, and/or jurisdictions and by the types of organizations they belong to.

When entering the profiles of people, systems, and organizations into an IS plan, planners do so with the expectation that profiles will match the descriptions of task assignees. Once assigned to a task, an agent can become committed to sharing information acquired by executing the task as specified by the (modeled) IS practices.

All modeling is done via input forms. At all times, even if only minimal data has been entered, an IS plan can be visualized, analyzed, diagnosed, and applied to people and systems profiled as members of organizations.

figure.title: Sample IS modeling form in Channels - Information flow form

section.para: By using Channels to build IS plans, planners produce:

listitem.para: a reusable, transportable model of informations sharing (best) practices
actionable, personalized information sharing guidelines (IS practices applied to profiled agents)
information flow analytics and visualizations
detected information sharing gaps, bottlenecks, single points of failure, and other issues

section.para: A model of information sharing practices is visualized primarily as information flow maps. Information flow maps depict (specifications of) tasks connected by information flows.

Channels automatically detects issues in an IS plan (upwards of 90 different types of issues). Issues are communicated to planners visually (tasks and flows drawn in red) and in other ways as well (issues panels throughout, all-issues table, issues summary report). The entire set of outstanding issues is recalculated with every change planners make to the plan. Planners can manually indicate issues that Channels cannot detect, usually because the specific issues require domain knowledge.

An issue has a description, a list of suggested remediations, and a severity level (minor, major, severe, extreme). The severity of an issue is either a constant for the type of issue, or it is calculated from the potential cascade of task failures attributable to the issue, in which case the severity is set by the most severe risk not mitigated or the most valuable gain not realized because of the failure.

figure.title: Examples of issue detection and reporting

section.para: Issue diagnostics is one of many kinds of analysis Channels performs on an IS plan. Another is failure impact analysis. Channels can show what would happen should a planned task not be performed or should some information not be shared as planned.

Other questions Channels can answer about IS practices once modeled are:
Where would an element for information come from or end up according to plan?
Would it arrive in time?
How is it transformed along the way?

Channels applies the modeled IS practices to actual people and systems based on the roles they play in organizations. The results are personalized IS guidelines that can be accessed online by participants in the plan and printed.
By applying modeled IS practices to known people and systems in organizations, Channels can determine how organizations ought to be networked for an IS plan to be realized.

figure.title: An organization's network based on an IS plan

section.para: While the effort required to model IS practices far exceeds that of simply drawing information flow maps using a drawing tool, the benefits of modeling IS practices using Channels are substantial and include the automated generation of personalized IS guidelines, issue detection, and analyses that illuminate the properties and consequences of applying these practices.
Channels is to information sharing what spreadsheets are to financial planning, and what Business Process Modeling is to business operations.

section.title: Information sharing plan
section.para: An Information Sharing Plan (IS Plan) specifies the information sharing commitments required of people and systems (agents) in roles of responsibility to fulfill the missions of their organizations, before, during, and/or after events of significance.

Agents achieve goals that fulfill their organizations' missions by executing, individually or as teams, tasks assigned to them. By executing their assigned tasks, agents directly manage risks, achieve gains, and/or produce information needed by other tasks. Information sharing flows connect tasks that produce information with tasks that need it. Information can be shared between people, people and systems, or between systems, over transmission media or face-to-face. Sharing can be subject to policies.

When planners define a task, they either identify or profile the agents to be assigned to it. Profiling task assignees can be done more or less broadly by specifying them in terms of their organizations, roles, qualifications and/or jurisdictions. Agents can be bound by information sharing commitments whenever they are assigned to tasks that are connected by flows to other tasks. Agents commit to share information they acquire when doing a task with some or all agents who execute flow-connected tasks. Recipient agents commit not to use the information for other purposes.

It is important to understand that an information sharing plan is not an action plan. Unlike Business Process Modeling, the objective of Information Sharing Planning (ISP) is not to optimize, script, or automate activities. The overarching objective of building an IS plan is to ensure that information does flow as required in order to successfully manage risks and capture opportunities.

Task sequencing is however not entirely absent from an IS plan. A task triggered by information requires the prior execution of another task producing it. Such sequencing constraints do not typically apply to all tasks in an IS plan, and thus an IS plan will most often not dictate a unique sequence for all tasks.

This is a good thing. Attempting to define a precisely orchestrated action plan for organizations without a central authority is almost always an exercise in futility. So, while an IS plan certainly captures what needs to be done, the focus is squarely on how information needs to flow to ensure that mission-accomplishing tasks are successful. The details of exactly how these tasks are to be executed is outside the scope of ISP.

section.title: IS plan = IS practices + environment
section.para: An IS plan can be understood as information sharing practices applied to an environment. Information sharing practices are definitions of tasks and the information flows between them. An environment is composed of agents (people and systems) in roles of responsibility within organizations. These agents are assigned to flow-connected tasks and consequently have information sharing commitments.

figure.title: Flow-connected tasks in the IS practices model of an IS plan

section.para: In order to separate (decouple) IS practices and environment, it is recommended to model IS practices without mentioning actual organizations, people, or systems. It is best to specify tasks as being executed by "disembodied" roles from types of organizations (e.g. a "forensic autopsy" is to be carried by a "coroner" from a "county health office"). IS practices models that are not attached to a particular environment can be applied, possibly with some local adaptations, to various environments.

figure.title: Profile of an actual organization populating the environment of an IS plan

section.para: An IS plan's environment identifies the actual people or systems that play the organizational roles mentioned in the IS practices model (or IS model for short). For example, planners could build an IS model for responding to an epidemic outbreak at the state level, and then apply the same IS model to different states, each state being a different environment with its own organizations and role-assigned agents.

Note that there is not yet explicit support in the current release of Channels for separately managing the IS model and environment of an IS plan, or for explicitly composing IS plans by applying one reusable IS model to different environments. A forthcoming release of Channels will provide such support. In the meanwhile, planners are strongly encouraged to follow the above best practice of keeping the IS model as decoupled as possible from the IS plan's environment.

section.title: Event phases, goals, and segments
section.para: The scope of an IS plan is primarily set by identifying the events of significance the plan must address. (A plan's scope is also set by the list of organizations that are expected to participate in the plan.) An event of significance (or event, for short) is something that is true somewhere for some time and that challenges, in and of itself, the mission of one or more organizations by introducing risks or by creating opportunities for gains. Organizations assign their agents to tasks that mitigate these risks or make gains. An event can bring different risks or opportunities to different organizations. For example, an explosion at a refinery, clearly an event of significance, endangers the lives of workers, would likely cause financial losses to insurers, and might profit commodity traders.

The events in an IS plan are not actual events that did or will occur at specific times and locations. They are implicitly types of events that might happen in some indeterminate future in some location that can be identified (e.g., in New York City) or specified (e.g., in a large urban area).

Risks and opportunities can exist in the before, during, or after phases of an event (event phases). Typically the purpose of tasks in a "before" phase of an event will be to cause or prevent the event. Tasks in a "during" phase of an event will normally be about responding to the event as it is unfolding in order to minimize its negative consequences or maximize positive outcomes. Tasks in an "after" phase will often deal with recovering from the aftermath of an event, or reaping its rewards.

An IS plan will typically focus on at least one, and at most a few, events of significance, and cover one or more phases for each of these events. Events within the scope of a plan are a combination of events that happen outside the control of the participants of the plan (so-called incidents) and of events caused by planned tasks (and are thus under the control of participants).

figure.title: Events in the scope of an IS plan

section.para: An IS plan should also address only a small, manageable number of organizational risks or opportunities stemming from events in scope. It is recommended, when starting on a new IS plan, not to involve too many organizations having too many goals in too many phases of too many events. It is better to start small and focused and then grow as needed.

Information sharing plans typically deal with more than one event phase, and they can involve a sizable number of organizations. Because plans can become quite large, planners break them into smaller, more manageable units of planning called segments.

An IS plan segment covers only one phase of one event, possibly in the context of some other past or currents events. For example, a segment might focus on responding to a "stock price rally" (event phase focus) during "a volatile market" and after a prior "hostile takeover attempt" (context events).

A segment might address all or only some of the organizational goals associated with an event phase. In other words, more than one segment may be dedicated to a given event phase, with each segment addressing a different list of organizational goals. Two segments should not address the same goal for the same event phase.

figure.title: Organizational goals addressed in a segment

section.para: A segment lists one or more organization goals (a segment without goals is an issue detected by Channels). A goal is either a risk to an organization (or type of organization) to be mitigated, or a gain to be realized by an organization (or type of organization). Each risk is categorized from a list of types of risks derived from actuarial risk management taxonomies. Each gain is also categorized from a list that is the "mirror image" of the risk types. Risks are rated as minor, major, severe, or extreme. Gains are rated as low, medium, high, or highest. Planners can indicate if a risk is implicitly mitigated or a gain implicitly realized once the event phase covered by the segment is terminated.

Every task and flow in an IS plan belongs to one and only one segment. A segment should contain all the flow-enabled tasks that directly achieve the segment's goals, plus flow-enabled tasks on which goal-achieving tasks depend to start, terminate, or succeed.

Segments are normally not disjoint; flows usually connect one or more tasks in one segment to tasks in another. Furthermore a task in one segment might initiate the event phase addressed by the other segment either by causing an event or terminating it. Initiation of an event starts the "during" phase of that event and terminates its "before" phase. Termination of an event starts the "after" phase of that event.

figure.title: The inter-connected segments in an IS plan

section.title: Flows and tasks
section.para: Flows and the tasks they connect are the building blocks of the IS practices model in an IS plan. A task describes an action carried out at some location and for some purpose by one or more agents. Agents act to fulfill the responsibilities of the roles bestowed on them by organizations. The agents expected to carry out a task can be identified by any combination of name, role, jurisdiction, and organization. The executor of a task may be identified only partially (for example, by role and organization only) so that more than one person or system will match the profile and get assigned to the task. According to a task's definition, those assigned to the task are expected to carry it out either as a team or on their own. The timing aspects of a task execution can be given, namely, how long the task takes to complete and how soon it repeats, if at all. A task might cause or prevent an event.
Tasks are considered useful if they:

listitem.para: directly achieve goals (mitigate risks or capture gains)
initiate or terminate (phases of) events
or produce information needed by other useful tasks

section.para: Tasks can be triggered or terminated by:

listitem.para: direct awareness of events
receiving notifications
receiving requests for information

section.para: An information flow links a task that produces information to a task that consumes it. A flow is characterized by:

listitem.para: whether the flow is a notification, a request, or a reply
the information communicated, down to its elements, each with optional secrecy classifications and sourcing and handling instructions
whether the situation (event phase and event context) in which the source task is being executed (e.g., responding to a suspected attack) is also to be communicated
the intent of the flow (alarm, announcement, command, feedback or report)
whether the flow is conditional on task failure
the mode of communication (request vs. notification, unicast vs. multicast vs. broadcast)
restrictions, if any, based on shared organization membership or location of the source and/or target of the flow
a list of preferred transmission media (phone, face-to-face, etc.)
the urgency (maximum delay from earliest availability if a notification, or maximum delay from request if a reply)
the impacts, if any, the communication may have (it might trigger or terminate a task)
instructions on how to carry out the task
policies that mandate or prohibit sharing

section.para: A task can have information needs (information agents require to execute the task), information capabilities (information acquired by the execution of the task that can then be shared), or both. An information flow implicitly specifies an information need of the receiving task that is satisfied by an implied information capability of the sending task. Planners can explicitly define the information needs and capabilities of a task.

Explicitly specifying an information need of a task allows Channels to automatically verify if the need is satisfied (Are all elements supplied in a timely manner by incoming flows?) and to find information-capable tasks that could be connected by flows to satisfy an information need.

figure.title: An information need appears in a flow map as a flow without a source task

section.para: Specifying an explicit information capability allows Channels to automatically verify if the sharing capability is being exercised and to find tasks to connect to so that the capability might satisfy their needs.

figure.title: An information capability appears in a flow map as a flow with no target task

section.title: Entities
section.para: An IS plan references by name various agents, places, roles, organizations, events, transmission media and phases of events. These are referred to in ISP as entities. An ISP entity is anything that can be named in an IS plan but is neither a task nor information. An ISP entity is always unambiguously referenced by name in a plan, its segments, tasks, and flows, or in the profiles of other entities. There can only be one agent named "John Doe", only one event named "lawsuit filed," etc.

There are actual entities and there are types of entities. Actual entities (“Jane Smith”, “ACME Inc.”, “Morristown, Morris County, NJ, USA,” etc.) are categorized by types of entities (“Senior executive”, “Corporation”, “City” etc.). Entity types can refine other entity types (a “Senior executive” is a kind of “Executive”).

Actual entities can be categorized by entity types of the same kind (agents are categorized by agent types etc.) but entity types themselves can be categorized by other entity types, thus forming implicit typologies.

An agent is either a person or an information system (system for short). An agent is capable of sending or receiving notifications and sending and answering queries. An agent has contact information and availability (24/7 by default). An agent's clearance is a list of secrecy classifications (e.g., NATO Top Secret and US Gov. Secret).

An agent type can be thought of as a qualification that can be shared by different agents (e.g., "Adult" or "Registered driver"). An agent type is not to be confused with a role. A role implies responsibilities, whereas an agent type denotes qualifications or status.
An agent can be flagged as a system (non-human).

When a group of agents are indistinguishable from a planning perspective (for example, call center operators), they can be profiled as a single archetype agent (for example, "a call center operator").

When the identity of an agent is to be resolved by associating the agent with one or more users of Channels, the agent is marked as a placeholder (more on this later). Agents are references in the definitions of tasks and organizations (their members and their supervisors).

An organization is a group of agents organized to accomplish a mission. An organization assigns roles of responsibility to the persons and systems that act on its behalf. An organization has contact information and may contain other organizations. An organization may have information sharing agreements with other organizations to formalize the sharing commitments its members have with members of other organizations. Organizations are referenced in the definitions of a plan itself (organizations that are expected to participate), in segments (organizational risks), tasks, and as parents of other organizations.

A role is a set of powers and responsibilities bestowed by an organization to an agent acting on behalf of the organization. A role assignment may be restricted to a jurisdiction (a place). A role is always an entity type. Roles are referenced in tasks and in organizations (roles played by their members).

A place is either a geographical area (some city, county, state, country, natural preserve, etc.) or a known location (some train station, building, etc.). A place can be contained in another (for example, a building can be in a campus). Places are referenced in a plan's definition (the plan's default locale), in events (an event and an event type can both be located to a place), in tasks (location of execution and jurisdiction of assignees), and in organizations (address and jurisdictions of members).

A phase names a time period relative to events. A phase is either set to before, during, or after events. Typical phases are “Preparing,” “Responding,” and “Recovering”. A phase is always an entity type. Phases are referenced in a plan's definition (phases in scope), and in segments (event phase in focus and event phases in context).

A transmission medium is a means by which agents transmit information to one another. Transmission media may or may not be technology-based. A medium is either unicast (transmits to a single, known agent), multicast (transmits to multiple, known agents), or broadcast (little to no control over who receives the transmission).

A transmission medium can delegate transmissions to other media. For example, VoIP can interface with Telephones. The security of a medium is expressed in terms of secrecy classifications. A transmission medium is always an entity type. Transmission media are referenced in the definitions of communication channels. Communication channels are used to define information flows, needs and capabilities, and the contact information of agents and organizations.

section.title: Secrecy, security and clearances
section.para: Planners can define one or more classification systems in an IS plan and make use of them classify elements of information, define transmission media security, and to set the security clearances of (actual) agents.
A secrecy classification has a name (e.g. “NATO”) and an ordered list of secrecy levels (“Restricted,” “Confidential,” “Secret,” “Focal Top Secret,”and “Cosmic Top Secret”).
Each classification system has a unique name and consists of a list of classification levels ranked from lowest (bottom) to highest (top).
Agents can be given security clearances. Clearances are expressed as classification levels (no more than one per classification system).
How secure a transmission medium type is, is defined by the highest classification levels of the information it can transmit without infringing upon security requirements.
Elements of information shared or to be shared can each be given classification levels, as well as indications of the source and special handling instructions.
Secrecy and security issues that are automatically detected include:

listitem.para: Classified information transmitted over an insufficiently secure channel
A commitment to share classified information with an agent who has insufficient clearances
Receiving classified information and then disseminating it with reduced classification

section.title: The meaning of information in ISP
section.para: Tasks and flows are defined in terms of information needed, uncovered and shared. Information is named and is broken into atomic elements. Each element of information is named, can be given security classifications and can be annotated with a description and handling instructions.

Elements of information sent from a task can be described as the result of transforming elements received in the execution of the task. An element of information (EOI) sent can be the same as an EOI received, can be an EOI received but renamed, or can be an aggregation of EOIs received (for example a count, a synthesis,etc.).
An element of information is considered atomic for the purposes of a plan; it is the indivisible unit of transmission and transformation. Once aggregated, an EOI can not be "split apart".

The notion of the plurality of an element is left undefined. For example, if "suspicious activity report" information contains the element "suspect profile," then it is possible that there will be more than one suspect profile in a report.

When analyzing flows, Channels is not concerned with what the information actually means. Channels has no domain knowledge to infer from. Rather, it cares about whether or not two flows concern the same information, and whether an element of information is the same as, or is the transformation of, another element of information.

If the information in two flows have the same name, it does not necessarily mean that they represent, conceptually, the same information. Two tasks performed respectively by a EOC commander and a corporate CEO might both need a "situation assessment," but they would likely not need the same kind of situation assessment with the same elements of information (even if the elements themselves have identical names).

In Channels, identically named flows, needs, and capabilities (uppercase vs. lowercase and extra spaces are ignored) are explicitly meant to represent the same kind of information (they are synonymous) if and only if they connect to the same tasks (one flow may be a "send" and the other one a "receive"). Similarly, identically named elements of information are meant to represent the same atom of information if only if the information they compose have the same meaning.

Agents executing a task receive and send information. The information they receive and send may have different names yet have common elements of information. For example, the "suspect profile" element of a sent "suspicious activity report" may be the same as the "suspect description" element of a received "security tip", and it may be the same as the "suspect profile" of received "BOLO" information.

Alternately, an element sent may aggregate elements received. Aggregation combines many elements into a single element, with loss of data. For example, a "suspects count" element aggregates "suspect profile" elements into a single number, losing the details of the individual profiles. Counting is only one of many possible kinds of aggregation. A "threat level," for example, might aggregate a great deal of different elements into a high vs. low rating.

In order to track the dissemination of information, it necessary to indicate when sent elements are the result of renaming or aggregating received elements. Channels need only differentiate between those two kinds of element transformation in order to track the dissemination of information. The description field of an element of information can be used to provide more details about the specific nature of an aggregation.

Issue detection takes element renaming and aggregation into account. For example, while it may be acceptable to declassify aggregated elements, it is not acceptable to declassify a renamed, classified element.

section.title: Task assignments and information sharing commitments
section.para: A task in an IS plan is a specification of some action to be done or some decision to be made either all the time, upon witnessing the start or end of an event, or upon receiving a notification or a request for information. In defining a task, planners normally do not identify by name the actual agents to be assigned to the tasks, but rather describe their profile in terms of their qualifications (as agent types), roles, jurisdictions (as named places or types of places), and/or organizations (by name or by type).

What is meant by "directly or indirectly"? Let's say that FBI (an actual organization) is categorized as both a "Law Enforcement Agency" and "Federal Agency", and "Federal Agency" is categorized as a "Government Agency", then the FBI would directly match "Law Enforcement Agency" and indirectly match "Government Agency".

Any agent assigned to a task that sends information to another task (i.e. is connected by a flow targeting the other task) commits to share it with some or all agents assigned to the task receiving the information. A task assigned to three agents with a flow targeting another task assigned to two agents might imply six different information sharing commitments, one from each assignee of the information-producing task to each assignee of the information-consuming task.

If the flow is annotated as "to every", then the commitment is to share it with all assignees of the target task, otherwise the flow is "to any" and the commitment is to share with at least one of the assignees of the target task.

Not all assignees of the target task are necessarily eligible to be beneficiaries of information sharing commitments (commitments for short). Commitments can be subject to restrictions or prohibitions. Commitments can be restricted to agents in the same or different organization or in organizations with the same parent organizations. They can be restricted to agents in the same location or different location, to agents who are supervisors. Commitments can be restricted to one self, which may sound odd until one realizes that an agent might uncover information doing a task, keep it to oneself and start another task on the basis of this information (an agent has in essence notified itself to trigger another task). Commitments can also be restricted to "someone else" or to agents in both the same organization and location.

figure.title: Sharing commitments derived from assignments to tasks connected by a flow

section.para: A flow can be marked as "prohibited", in which case no commitments are implied, no matter who is assigned to the source and target tasks. Flow prohibition is used to specify "exceptions to the rules" in IS plans. (More on that later.)

An agent's information sharing procedures (IS procedures) is the list of all task assignments for the agent plus all associated information sharing commitments. An agent's information sharing guidelines are produced from the IS procedures computed by Channels for that agent.

Many analytics in Channels (dissemination, impact failure, network, various type of issues) depend on the computing of IS procedures for all agents in an IS plan. Because matching of profiles involves entity types, the proper design of typologies (for agents, roles, places, organizations etc.) is key to successfully building IS plans.

section.title: Expressing exceptions by overriding tasks and flows
section.para: It is at times necessary to express "exceptions to the rule" when modeling IS practices. For example, IS practices might dictate that all employees alert their supervisors if they become aware of suspicious activities, whereas managers, who are also employees, should not alert their supervisors but rather directly contact the head of security.

Such exceptions in IS practices can be captured by defining overriding tasks and by defining prohibited flows from the overriding tasks that are otherwise equivalent to flows from the overriden tasks.

figure.title: Overriding tasks and flows to express exceptions in IS practices

section.para: When task A (for example, "managers detecting threats") overrides task B ("employees detecting threats") , agents assigned to task A are not assigned to the overridden task B. Furthermore, if task A is annotated as "prohibited," then no agent is assigned to task A and any agent assignable to task B is not assigned to task B either. This allows planners to express exceptions such as "all employees leave the building except for managers".

A flow A overrides another flow B if:
they both have the same name (dsicounting case and extra blanks)
the source task of flow A overrides the source task of flow B
and the target task of flow A is the same as or overrides the target of flow B

If an agent has sharing commitments computed from flow A then they replace any and all commitments for this agent computed from the overridden flow B. Furthermore, if overriding flow A is prohibited, then whoever would have commitments from flow A has commitments from neither flow A nor from overriden flow B.

section.title: Information sharing agreements
section.para: An information sharing agreement is a formal recognition that an organization commits to share certain information with another organization.

Channels finds the information sharing commitments of agents between each pair of organizations and, for each "networking" pair, aggregates the commitments into distinct "information sharing relationships". Each information sharing relationship is a summary of sharing commitments for particular information (the agents in the commitments and their roles are abstracted out). For example, an information sharing relationship would summarize the fact that members of Bank A commit to share fraud information with members of Bank B. For each such relationship, planners can indicate whether an information sharing commitment has been formalized, and attach or link to the document formalizing the agreement.

figure.title: The sharing agreements of an organization

section.para: An organization may require that its sharing commitments with other organizations be covered by sharing agreements. If there is an exception to this rule, an issue is raised by Channels. Furthermore, if a sharing agreement is confirmed but not documented, an issue is also raised. Note that in applying these constraints, Channels does not distinguish when both organizations belong to a common parent organization and when they do not.

section.title: Descriptions, instructions and attachments
section.para: Not everything in the definition of an IS plan can be captured neatly as "structured data". Some important data is best conveyed with free form text or via attached documents.

Most forms used to define elements of an IS plan contain a text field called "description" where planners can optionally enter explanatory or documentary text. Instead of a description field, tasks and flows have instruction fields. Descriptions and instructions are not examined by Channels (Channels is indifferent to their content) but they do appear in IS guidelines generated by Channels.

figure.title: A segment, like most elements of an IS plan, has a description

section.para: Sometimes an element of a plan or the plan itself can be documented by a PDF or a Web page or illustrated by a photo or a video. Channels allows planners to attach documents to a plan element by uploading them or linking to them in the context of that element.

An attachment is optionally given a name (its URL is the default name). It is also given a type. Different kinds of plan elements allow different kinds of attachment types. Certain types of attachments have different properties.

The types of attachments recognized by Channels are:
Reference - Reference documentation. Movies or graphics attached to tasks and flows as references are highlighted as icons that, when clicked, show the graphic or video, assuming that the Web browser supports the media type.
Media reference attachment
Picture - A picture document is used to produce icons displayed in flow maps. Channels automatically converts pictures into icons it uses in various visualizations. Only one picture per plan element is allowed.
Picture attachment and use as icon
Policy - Document containing policy statements participants need to be aware of.
Mandating policy - Document containing policy statements that mandate tasks or flows.
Forbidding (prohibiting) policy - Document containing policy statements that restrict tasks or flows. Note that attaching a prohibiting policy document to a flow or a task does not in and of itself prohibit it. The policy might prohibit execution of the task or of the flow only in some but not all circumstances (and in ways too complex to be captured formally in the IS plan). To prohibit a flow or a task in an IS plan, planners must explicitly mark it as prohibited (via a check box in the task or flow form).
Prohibiting policy attachment and prohibited flow
MOU - Memorandum of understanding documenting sharing agreements.
Tags - Predefined tags (see next section), attachable to an IS plan as a whole.
Info standards - Predefined elements of information implied by tags, attachable to an IS plan as a whole.
Help - Used to provide support documentation.

section.title: Tagging
section.para: Tags provide a useful mechanism for the ad hoc cataloguing of elements of an IS plan that otherwise may have nothing else in common. Most elements of a plan can be tagged. An element can have multiple, comma-separated tags.
A planner can see all the tags used in an IS plan and look up all elements of the plan tagged with a given tag.

The set of all tags in an IS plan is called the tag domain. Tags can be grouped by named sub-domains. When a tag belongs to a sub-domain, the tag is written as the name of the sub-domain followed by a colon followed by the name of the tag. For example, "esf:transportation" is the tag "transportation" in the tag sub-domain "esf". A planner can easily look up all elements tagged with tags belonging to a given sub-domain. Tag sub-domains can be predefined and attached to an IS plan (an attachment of type "Tag") prior to the tags being used. Note that tags need not be predefined to be used in tagging plan elements. Files defining tag sub-domains attached to an IS plan

A special kind of tag sub-domain is called an "information standard". Each information standard tag is associated with a list of predefined elements of information, each with a name, and optional description and handling instructions. When a flow is tagged with an information standard tag, its elements of information can be auto-populated with those associated with the tag. An information standard tag sub-domain is added to an IS plan by attaching a file defining them (an attachment of type "Info standards").

figure.title: Tagging a flow with an info standard tag to auto-populate its elements of information

section.para: Documents defining basic or info standard tag sub-domains must adhere to simple formatting rules. For basic tag sub-domains, the rules are:

listitem.para: A blank line or line starting with # is ignored.
Each line contains a single fully named tag (e.g. esf:transportation) or comma-separated tags (e.g. esf:transportation, esf:hazmat).

figure.title: File defining basic tags for the "esf" tagging sub-domain

section.para:
For info standard tag sub-domain files, the rules are:
A blank line or line starting with # is ignored.
A tag name is given in full and starts at the beginning of a line.
The elements of information for a tag each appear indented on a separate line beneath the tag.
The optional description and handling instructions are separated each by a hyphen.

figure.title: File defining info standard tags in the "cap" tagging sub-domain

section.title: How is ISP different from BPM?
section.para: The most frequently asked question about Information Sharing Planning is "How is different from Business Process Management"?
To answer this question, one must first consider that Information Sharing Planning (ISP) is part of something larger called Information Sharing Management.

Information Sharing Management (ISM) is a set of technologies and best practices that help communities of organizations share information more effectively in order to achieve their missions when preparing for, responding to, and recovering from actual events. Information Sharing Planning (ISP) produces the information sharing procedures that organizations apply when actually sharing information. ISP analyzes these procedures for continuous improvement.

Business Process Management (BPM) helps enterprises become more efficient, more effective, and more agile in how they each operate. Business Process Modeling captures and analyzes business processes for continuous improvement.
Because ISP relates most closely to Business Process Modeling, the question should be recast to "How do Information Sharing Management and Business Process Management differ"?
Other questions are "Can ISM and BPM be used together"? and "How do the markets for BPM and ISM compare"?

section.title: Differences
section.para: BPM and ISM tackle different problems from different perspectives.

BPM focuses "inward" on a single (but possibly extended) enterprise. It looks at how the enterprise responds internally to events, and at how it renders services to its customers. The end is maximizing value creation while minimizing costs. The means is business process improvement.

ISM focuses "outward" on (often ad hoc) communities of organizations. It looks at how organizations depend on one another to get the information they need to execute tasks that achieve organizational goals. The end is minimizing the impacts of systemic risks and maximizing the capture of opportunities. The means is better information sharing.

While there is conceptual overlap (both ISM and BPM involve tasks, events, and communications) and even though they both use somewhat similar-looking visualizations (directed graphs), ISM and BPM have very different world views. BPM looks at the operations of an enterprise, whereas ISM looks at the information flows between a community of organizations. They also differ in their goals: BPM optimizes enterprise value creation whereas ISM reduces the impacts of systemic risks.

section.title: Similarities
section.para: ISM and BPM are structurally similar in a number of ways.
Both BPM and ISM are concerned with optimization. BPM optimizes the design and execution of business processes, whereas ISM optimizes information sharing procedures and their application.

BPM and ISM each has a modeling component (business process modeling, information sharing planning) and a deployment component (modeled business processes are deployed as work flows, information sharing plans are deployed as information sharing procedures).

Both BPM and ISM integrate with existing systems and technologies. BPM integrates with EAI (Enterprise Application Integration), SOA (Service-Oriented Architecture) and EBA (Event-Based Architecture) technologies. ISM integrates primarily with Communication Technologies, Enterprise Directories, and SOA.
Finally, both BPM and ISM require the participation of analysts. BPM involves business process engineers and ISM involves information sharing planners.

chapter.title: Using Channels
chapter.para: As stated in Chapter 1, Channels is a collaborative Web application information sharing planners use to build, analyze, and deploy information sharing plans (IS plans).
A Channels server can host multiple IS plans. Users can be given access to more than one plan hosted on a Channels server.

IS plans are versioned. Each plan has one development version being developed, possibly one production version that can no longer be changed, and zero or more retired versions (prior production versions).

section.title: User Roles
section.para: Channels recognizes three user roles: administrator, planner, and participant.

A Channels server has at least one administrator. An administrator has unlimited rights and privileges over the Channels server and the plans hosted on it. A user is given planner privileges by an administrator for some or all plans on a Channels server. Planners jointly develop, review, and deploy IS plans for which they have been given planner status by an administrator. Users can be given participant access to some or all plans by an administrator. Participants view their IS procedures and respond to surveys from planners about issue resolution. A user can be a planner for some plans, a participant for others, and have no access whatever to plans for which he/she is neither planner nor participant.
An administrator implicitly also has planner privileges over all plans hosted on the Channels server. A planner for a given plan implicitly also has participant privileges.
An administrator of a Channels server can:

listitem.para: configure the Channels server
add new plans
delete existing plans
move a development version of a plan into production, retiring the previous production version, if any
assign users to plans and change their user roles

section.para: A planner of an IS plan (and all administrators) can:

listitem.para: view all non-retired versions of the plan
modify the development version
associate participants with agents (production and development versions only)
view plan analytics
vote with other planners to put the development version into production
launch, access, and close online surveys of selected planners and participants about issues in the plan

section.para: A participant in an IS plan (and all its planners and all administrators) can:

listitem.para: view the IS guidelines report for the agent he/she is associated with
provide feedback about his/her IS guidelines
access and respond to online surveys

if a version of a plan is marked as a "template"
view (but not modify) the details of that version
view all analytics for that version

section.title: Channels Pages
section.para: Channels is a Web application composed of a number of Web pages, some of which behave not unlike desktop applications.

The Channels pages are:
The login page
The "renew password" page
The Home page
The administration page
The information sharing model page
The assignments and commitments page
The issues summary page
The participants list page
The IS guidelines page
Various other pages which handle login failures, system errors, session timeouts, etc.

section.title: Logging In
section.para: When accessing Channels, an unrecognized user is presented with a login screen. The user is asked to enter user name and password. To avoid being asked to login again after quitting without signing out, the user can check the "Remember me..." check box (the browser must allow cookies for this to work).
Upon successful login, a user is taken to the Channels Home Page.
Note that users can not self-register on a Channels server. They must be added together with their initial passwords by a Channels administrator.

A user who has forgotten his/her password or user id can request a new password. The new password together with a user id reminder is sent via email (the user must remember the email address used when registering him/her into the Channels server).

section.title: Home Page
section.para: The Home page lets the user select a plan from all plans they are authorized to see. A plan is always selected by default upon logging in. The home pages of administrators, planners, and participants have different content reflecting their differing privileges in regards to the selected plan.
The administrator's home page is the same as a planner's home page except that the administrator is given access to the administration page.

A planner can
edit the development version of the plan and view its production version (same interface but edit form fields are disabled)
visually explore the task assignments and information sharing commitments (the IS procedures) generated by the plan
view metrics about issues detected in the plan
assign participants to agents in the plan and view their IS guidelines (IS procedures in report format)
View the information needs reports of all participants

A participant in a normal (non-template) plan can only access the IS guidelines generated from the production version for the agent he/she is assigned to. A participant can not send messages to other users from within the collaboration panel, but is able to read messages broadcast to all users (or news) by planners (see below).

An IS plan can be marked as a template. This indicates that there is nothing sensitive in the plan and that a participant can see not only his/her participation in the plan (personal IS guidelines, info needs report), but also the entire plan itself in its production version. A participant (and all other users) can see but not modify the production version of the plan.

figure.title: Channels home page for participants of a "template" plan

section.title: Home page collaboration and settings panel
section.para: The collaboration and settings tabs in the home page allow planners to communicate with other users via messages, calendar events, and surveys.

The "About Me" tab lets a user edit his/her full name and private email, and change their password. If the user is a participant in the plan, the user can update the contact information for the agent he/she has been assigned to.
Participants can only read the broadcast messages from planners which appear in the "News" tab, but cannot reply to or comment on these messages.
Planners (and thus administrators) can both send and receive messages.
Planners can add events to a Google calendar associated to the plan (as configured by administrators in the Administration Page). Events can be viewed by all users of the plan.
Planners can launch surveys and send them to users. A user can see all surveys received and the status of each survey, and can access a survey in order to respond to it.
A user can modify data related to his/her identity as a user but also, if applicable, data related to the agent the user is represented by in the plan.

section.title: Feedback panel
section.para: A feedback mechanism is available from the Home page to all users of Channels. It allows users to ask questions, make recommendations, and report problems. The feedback is sent via email to an address configured for the plan by an administrator. The email address of the user sending the feedback is included in the email. Further conversations can take place over email.
Note that feedback can also be sent from within IS guidelines.

section.title: Administration page
section.para: A Channels administrator (and only an administrator) can create new plans, retire existing plans, move the development version of a plan to production (and thus retire the production version if any), and register, disable, and assign per-plan access privileges to users. Administrators are also responsible for configuring the Channels server.

section.title: Plan creation and user privileges
section.para: The Administration page is accessible only to administrators of the Channels server.

section.title: External services
section.para: Channels relies on a number of external, online services:

listitem.para: Geonames and Google MapsTM for geolocation
SurveyGizmosTM for launching surveys and collecting the results
An email service (SMTP) to send emails
Google CalendarTM to communicate calendar events of interest to users

section.para: Access to an external service requires account identification, either in the form of user id and password or in the form of an API key. When Channels is used as a service, external service configurations are already taken care of. However when installing a Channels server, an Administrator must acquire access to these external services and configure Channels to use the correct account information.

Planners need to log into the SurveyGizmo survey service to browse collected data and get reports. Planners also need to log into Google Calendar to add, edit, or remove calendar events communicated in Channels.

section.title: Survey service: SurveyGizmo
section.para: Surveys launched and managed from within Channels are hosted and managed by the SurveyGizmo service.
A planner can access a survey sample and a survey report directly from within Channels.

figure.title: Access to surveys hosted by survey service

section.para: A planner can look at the questionnaire for a particular survey and see a report on the response to that survey.
Refer to the SurveyGizmo service's online help at http://surveygizmo.zendesk.com/home for more details on how to use their service.

section.title: Google calendar settings
section.para:
To setup a plan with its dedicated Google Calendar, an administrator must follow these steps:
Open up a Google account
Go to calendar settings and
grab the calendar's private key
grab the calendar's embedded URL (up to the '?' character)
Fill in the calendar configuration fields in the Administration page

figure.title: Calendar embedded URL and private key

section.title: Information Sharing Model Page
section.para: The information sharing model page is also known as the Plan Editor. It opens on the version (development or production) of a plan selected in the Home page. A user can only select plans for which he/she has planner privileges (unless the plan version is marked as a template).
Only the development version of a plan can be modified. A production version is “read-only.” In a read-only version, all form fields are disabled and no survey can be launched about issue resolution.

When the Plan Editor opens up on (a version of) a plan, Channels pre-selects a segment and a task within it. A segment and a task are always selected. The task with its “receive” and “send” information flows are shown “collapsed” and summarized.
If the plan is brand new, an empty task in the otherwise empty and untitled segment is selected. The last task in a segment cannot be removed. The last segment in a plan cannot be removed.

A planner can at any time switch segments, if more than one is defined. The tasks and information flows of the selected segment are visualized as a flow map (a directed graph). The selected task is highlighted (by a gray outlined rectangle) in the flow map.

The Plan Editor window has four principal components:
The segment bar at the top
The information flow map
The panels showing the selected task with its receives and sends at the bottom
The collaboration tab panels to the right

section.title: The segment bar
section.para: The segment bar identifies the currently selected segment within the plan. If applicable, a drop down menu gives the planner access to others segments within the plan.
The Help icon opens up this content for browsing in a separate window.

The left and right arrow buttons are Channels' "back and forward" buttons. The back button brings the Plan Editor to its previous state, that is, re-opening whatever panel was just closed or collapsed, showing the previous segment that was just switched from, etc. The forward button brings back the state the planner backed from.

The plan editor uses AJAX to provide a user experience similar to that of a "native" application. The "back and forward" buttons must be used instead of the browser's back and forward button which would navigate users out of the plan editor.

section.title: Show menu
section.para: The segment bar's "Show" menu gives access to:

listitem.para: The collaboration tab panels, if collapsed
The plan details panel
The segment details panel (clicking on the name of the segment is a shortcut to this panel)
The surveys panel
A map of all segments in the plan
All issues in the plan
The entity typologies panel
The plan index
Channels Help (this content)

section.title: Actions menu
section.para: The segment bar's "Action" menu enables the planner to act on the segment as a whole by:

listitem.para: Sending a message about the segment
Adding a new task
Adding or pasting a copied task
Adding an ad hoc issue to the segment
Pasting a copied attachment to the segment
Moving tasks from this segment to another

section.para: Other available actions include:

listitem.para: Undoing the last action (if possible)
Redoing the last undone action (if possible)
Removing the current segment from the plan
Logging out of Channels

section.title: Information flow map
section.para: The information flow map displayed in the Plan Editor provides a visualization of how information ought to flow in the situation that is the focus of the currently selected segment.

figure.title: Maximized flow map for a segment

section.para: Tasks are the nodes (icons over text) in the graph. Information needs, capabilities, and sharing flows are represented by the arrows. Tasks and flows are drawn in red if they have known issues. Green and red traffic lights represent the start and end of the event phase covered by the segment. Tasks that are triggered by the start of the segment are connected to the green traffic light icon. Tasks that terminate the event phase are linked to the red traffic light.

Information flows (information shared), information needs (information needed for carrying out, triggering, or terminating a task), and information capabilities (shareable information produced by carrying out a task) are shown as arrows. Single-headed arrows represent notifications. Double-headed arrows are request-replies, with the empty arrowhead pointing to the task that consumes the information request, and the solid arrowhead pointing to the task that consumes the answer (the requested information flows to it).

Small squares stand for to-be-determined tasks. An arrow from a task to a dot represents an information capability of the task (information produced by the task that can be shared for use in other, to-be-determined tasks). An arrow from a small square to a task represents an information need of the task (the task needs information possibly produced by other, to-be-determined tasks).

When risks and goals are shown in a flow map, they appear respectively as colored flags and stars connected to tasks (if they achieve a goal) and segment end icons (if goals are achieved by ending the segment's event phase).
Tasks within a blue-gray rectangle denote tasks from other segments that are connected by sharing flows to tasks in the segment being viewed.
The flow map legend is shown by clicking on the "Help" icon in the flow map's display controls.

section.title: Flow map display controls
section.para:
The flow map display controls at the top left corner of a flow map give planners options as to how the flow map is displayed. The controls allow planners to:
Show/hide information needs and capabilities
Show/hide goals achieved by tasks
Show/hide tasks and flows not marked as operational
Maximize/un-maximize the flow map
Reduce the flow map to fit
Show the flow map legend

Flow maps can become quite large. A flow map can be reduced to fit within the available space by clicking on the "resize-to-fit" view control. Clicking on the icon once more brings the flow map back to its full size.

figure.title: Flow map displayed at full size

section.para: A flow map can be maximized to use all of the screen space allocated to the Plan Editor by clicking on the "maximize" view control. A maximized flow map can also be reduced to fit. A flow map is un-maximized either by clicking once more on the "maximize" view control or by selecting a task or a flow within the map.

figure.title: Maximized flow map resized to fit

section.para: A flow map, by default, does not display risks and gains (goals) and how they relate to tasks or the segment as a whole. To display risks and gains, the planner must click on the "show goals" control. Clicking again hides the goals.

figure.title: Flow map showing goals achieved by tasks

section.para: A flow map, also by default, does not display information needs and capabilities (tasks connected by arrows to square dots). To display information needs and capabilities the planner must click on the "show needs and capabilities" control. Clicking again hides them.

figure.title: Flow map showing information needs and capabilities

section.para: Tasks and flow are by default marked as "operational." Planners can change the operational status of tasks and flows and then hide nonoperational tasks and flows from the flow map.

figure.title: Flow map showing nonoperational tasks and flows
Flow map hiding nonoperational tasks and flows

section.para: The planner can expand the height of the task, receives, and sends panels at the bottom, at the expense of the flow map, by pressing the "expand forms" view control. Clicking again un-expands the bottom panels.

figure.title: Task, sends and receives panels expanded

section.title: Collaboration tab panels
section.para: The collaboration tab panels on the right side of the Plan Editor allow a planner see who else is working on the plan and what changes they made recently. A planner can send messages to a single planner or to all users and can read received messages. The collaboration tab panels can be collapsed if more screen space for the flow map and task/flow forms is needed.

figure.title: Expanded collaboration tab panels in plan editor
How to expand collaboration tab panels when collapsed

section.title: Presence tab
section.para: The presence tab by default shows users currently logged in and who selected the current plan (and version) from their Home pages. The presence tab is automatically and regularly refreshed. A planner can ask to see all registered users whether or not they are logged in. A message can be addressed to a planner from the "more" menu.

figure.title: Presence tab showing only users logged into the plan
All users who can see this plan

section.title: Activities tab
section.para: The activities tab lists all the latest changes made to the plan in one place. Each change record contains the nature of the change, what plan element was changed, who did it, and when. If the plan element that was changed is still in the plan, then clicking on it takes the planner to it.

figure.title: All recent changes made to the plan

section.title: Messages tab
section.para: The messages tab enables planners (and only planners) to send personal messages to another user with access to the currently selected plan, or to broadcast messages to all planners or participants.
A planner can show or hide broadcasts (nonpersonal messages), and alternately look at messages received or sent.

Messages can be sent "internally," to be read only from within the messages tab, or they can be sent via email. Internal messages can be "resent" by email. Messages sent internally can also be deleted.

A message sent from the context of a plan element will include a reference to that element. The recipient of the message can click on that reference to be taken to the plan element, if the element still exists in the plan.

figure.title: Sending and receiving a message about a plan element (here a task)

section.para: Note that the messaging capabilities of Channels should be used only while planning and should not be used during emergencies.

section.title: Acquiring and releasing edit locks
section.para: More than one planner can concurrently work on a plan. "Collisions" between two planners attempting to modify the same plan element are prevented by allowing only one planner at a time to modify any given task, flow, entity, segment definition, or plan definition.

When a planner opens an edit form on a plan element, Channels attempts to grab an edit lock on behalf of the planner for that plan element. If another planner already owns the lock, the form is shown to the first planner with the editable fields disabled.
A lock on a plan element owned by a planner is released when the planner collapses or closes its edit form, or logs out. An inactive planner eventually loses all acquired locks.

The name of the owner of a lock appears to other planners usually in the place of the "actions" menu for the locked plan element. A message can be sent to the owner of a lock by clicking on his/her name.

A planner waiting for edit locks is notified with a message in the segment bar when the locks are released. The planner is then instructed to refresh the editor in order to acquire the locks and enable disabled edit forms.

section.title: Semantic proximity matching
section.para: Naming matters a lot in Channels. Entities are referenced by their unique names and are created when first named. Using different names for what is essentially the same role, type of organization, etc. would become a source of confusion and would undermine the usefulness of an IS plan. Whether the names of tasks, flows, information needs, capabilities, and information elements are different or the same determines whether needs are satisfied or satisfiable.
Channels uses semantic proximity matching to promote convergence between planners toward a consistent, shared vocabulary for a plan.

Semantic proximity matching works by looking for already used, similar names that could mean something close to the name currently being entered by a planner in a form. A drop down menu shows to the planner the alternate, semantically proximal names found. The planner may then elect to use a name already used instead of a new one with similar meaning.

section.title: Attaching documents
section.para: Plan elements are documented and annotated by attaching files to them. These files can either be uploaded to the Channels server, or they can be linked to from Channels if they are reachable over the Internet or over an intranet in which Channels operates.

Documents can be attached, copied, or detached. Attachments are assigned a type. Certain types of attachment, for example, the picture type and the tags type impact the behavior of Channels (icons are generated and used, tags are added to the tag domain, etc.) Attachments can be named. The default name of an attachment is its URL.
Uploading an attachment takes the planner to the platform's file chooser. Linking to a document requires only entering a URL (the http:// prefix is implied if not given).

section.title: Floating panels
section.para: Many panels in Channels are of the "floating" sort. They can be moved, resized, brought to the front and closed.

The following are floating panels:
Plan definition panel
Segment definition panel
Entity profile panel
Task assignments panel
Sharing commitments panel
Task overrides panel
Elements of information panel
Failure impact analysis panel
Dissemination analysis panel
Procedures map panel
Flow map legend panel
There can only be one entity profile panel opened at a time, only one task assignments panel, etc.

section.title: Tasks, receives and sends panels
section.para: The task, receives and sends panels at the bottom of the plan editor show summaries of the selected task (there is always a task that is selected) together with a list of summaries of its "receives" (the task's information needs and the information flows to it) and a list of its "sends" (the task's information capabilities and the information flows from it). Each summary can be expanded into a form for editing (if the development version of the plan was the one selected on the Home page).

Each of the summaries is prefixed with a colored bullet. The color of the bullet indicates how important a task or a flow is. The color indicates the calculated impact of the task or the flow failing completely. Blue indicates a minor impact, yellow is major, orange is severe, and red is extreme. Gray bullets are used when failure impact does not apply (information needs and capabilities).

Clicking on the summary of a task or flow expands it by opening its edit form. Channels automatically adapts the width of task and flow forms to provide ease of editing. Clicking on the summary closes the form.
Note that, with very few exceptions, any and all fields in any form in Channels can be left blank. Of course, leaving all fields in a form blank is of little value.

figure.title: Task, send and receive panels can be expanded

section.title: Editing a task
section.para: A task is defined by naming it, categorizing it, tagging it, and flagging it, or not, as operational and/or prohibited. (Remember, everything is optional.) It is further defined by stating where it is to be executed, by whom, in what role within what jurisdiction, and on behalf of what organization. Any of the location, agent, jurisdiction, role, and organization entities that specify a task can be left unnamed so as to imply that more than one agent can be assigned to the task. The names of entities can be indicated to refer to actual entities (Morristown, NJ, John Doe, ACME, etc.) or to types of entities (a city, a certified technician, a corporation, etc.).

The execution of a task can be set to be “as a team” to indicate that all assigned agents are to work together when carrying out the task. By default, assignees are each to execute the task independently.

A task is also described by how long it normally takes to complete, whether it repeats and how quickly, and whether it starts automatically with the segment (implying that the assigned agents would become aware on their own of the onset of the segment's event phase).
The purpose of a task can be stated as causing an event, terminating the event phase addressed by the segment, mitigating one or more risks, or achieving gains within the segment's scope.
Reference and policy documents can be attached to the task either by URL or by uploading them. Finally, the task can be given a brief, informal set of instructions.

As for any plan element, a planner can add issues to those automatically detected about the task. Issues added by a planner can later be removed by any other planner. Issues detected by Channels cannot be removed, but can be waived.

The task's "Show" menu opens various views on the task, namely:
The details of the task as an edit form - a shortcut is to click on the task's summary
The assignments panel - all agents that are assigned to the task
Override panel - showing tasks that override or are overridden by this task (the menu item is not shown if there are no overrides)
The dissemination panel - analysis of element of information dissemination to and from the task
Entity profile panels - for all entities referenced in the definition of the task
The task actions menu becomes available when the task is expanded into its edit form (and the planner has acquired exclusive editing rights). Actions that do not apply are grayed out.

The actions available from the task actions menu are:
Undo the planner's last change to any plan element, if applicable
Redo the planner's last undone change, if applicable
Send a message about the task
Take a copy of the task
Cut (copy and delete) the task
Paste a copied attachment to the task's documentation, if applicable
Paste the copied task, if any - apply the copied task's definition to this task
Create a new task in this segment that is a copy of the current task
Connect this task with flows from other tasks that can satisfy (partially or completely) the info needs of this task
Disintermediate this task - directly connect tasks that use this one as a "middleman" for information sharing, bypassing this task

section.title: Editing a "send" or "receive"
section.para: The first step in defining either an information need, an information capability, or an information flow is to name the information, identify its intent (command, alarm, announcement, report, or feedback), and list the elements of information.
The mode of communication is given as either notification or by-request (push or pull).
Planners can specify if the information would be shared only in case to task failure ("sends" only).

If an information flow (information that is shared) is a notification, then it can be made a broadcast (information will be shared with all agents assigned to the target task) or a unicast (information will be shared with at least one agent assigned to the target task).
Keep in mind that an information flow that is a “send” to its source task is a ”receive” to its target task. One is looking at a single flow from either of its two ends.

An information flow can be created by first adding an information need to a task (if necessary), then adding an information capability of the same name in another (also if necessary), and then connecting the need to the capability or vice-versa by setting the “from” or “to” field to the other task. Another way to create an information flow is to start from an information need or capability of a task and then name the task at the other end of the flow. If a task of that name does not exist, a new one is created and connected.

When specifying or determining the source or target of a flow, a planner can restrict the sources and targets to be within the same umbrella organization, within the same specific organization, or within the same location. Adding a restriction on a sharing flow may filter out sharing commitments that would otherwise be implied by the flow (e.g., by dropping any sharing commitment that crosses organizational boundaries).

A communication delay is set either to zero (communication is to happen without delay) or to some finite time interval. For an information need, the delay represents the timeliness requirement for being notified (maximum delay from time of availability), or for getting a response to a request (maximum time elapsed from the request). For an information capability, the delay represents how quickly the information could be produced and communicated. For an information flow, the delay represents a “quality of service” commitment.

The communication channels over which the information is to flow can be set for both an information need and for a notification information flow, but only when viewed from the notified task. The same is true for a requested information flow when viewed from the task that responds to a request. Alternate communication channels are listed in order of preference.

When editing a “send” or “receive,” a planner can set whether sharing would normally trigger or terminate a task. A notification could trigger or terminate the receiving task. It could also terminate the sending task, if sending the notification concludes the task that produced the information. A request could trigger the task that produces a reply.

Planners can attach documents to a “send” or “receive.” A document can be a reference, a mandating policy, a prohibiting policy, an unspecified policy (contains language that may impose both obligations and restrictions), or it can be an image provided as an illustration (for example, a screenshot). Note that attaching a prohibiting policy to an information flow does not prohibit the generation of information sharing commitments.
Instructions can be given as text in the definition of "sends" and viewed in the definitions of received information flows.

figure.title: Edit form for an information need
Edit form for an information capability
Edit form for an information flow (here a "receive")

section.para: Information needed, shareable, or to-be shared can be decomposed into named elements. Each element of information sent or shareable can be described and assigned individual secrecy classifications as well as handling instructions. Planners can indicate whether and how a "sent" element of information is related to a received element of information (is the same one but renamed, is it an aggregation of many received elements?).

An element sent is implicitly the same as one received if both are identically named and both comprise identically named incoming and outgoing information. If an element sent is in effect the same as one received but they have different names or comprise information with a different name, then planners need to indicate that the element sent renames the element received. If an element sent is a compilation/summation of multiple elements received, planners can identify the received elements that are aggregated into a sent element. Doing so enables Channels to track the planned dissemination of information.

To reduce the drudgery of defining elements of information, the list can be auto-populated by clicking on the magic wand icon. Clicking on the classifications "link" icon forces all elements to have the same classification. Clicking again removes the constraint.

figure.title: Editing shared or shareable elements of information

section.para: The elements of information of an information need do not have secrecy classifications, descriptions, special handling instructions, or transformation attributes. They do however have time-sensitivity attributes to indicate which of the elements are subject to the timing requirements of the information need they define.

The "More" menu of a "send" or "receive" combines access to "views" and to "actions". The menu in a collapsed "send" or "receive" differs from the menu when the edit form is expanded and the planner gains exclusive rights to make changes.

The menu of a collapsed information need allows the planner to:
Show or hide (expand or collapse) the edit form
Send a message about the information need
Undo the planner's last change to any plan element, if applicable
Redo the planner's last undone change, if applicable
Make a copy of the information need

The menu for an expanded information need additionally allows the planner to:
Edit the elements of an information need
