Add a new, ad hoc issue about the information need
Add a copied attachment to the information need's documentation, if applicable
Remove the information need

figure.title: Information need menus for collapsed and expanded edit forms

section.para:
The menu of a collapsed information capability allows the planner to:
Show or hide (expand or collapse) the edit form
Send a message about the information capability
Undo the planner's last change to any plan element, if applicable
Redo the planner's last undone change, if applicable
Make a copy of the information capability

The menu for an expanded information capability additionally allows the planner to:
Edit the information capability's elements
Add a new, ad hoc issue about the information capability
Add a copied attachment to the information capability documentation, if applicable
Remove the information capability

figure.title: Information capability menus for collapsed and expanded edit forms

section.para:
The menu of collapsed information flow allows the planner to:
Show or hide (expand or collapse) the edit form
Send a message about the information flow
View the information sharing commitments computed for this flow
View the failure impact analysis for this flow
View the information dissemination analysis for this flow
Undo the planner's last change to any plan element, if applicable
Redo the planner's last undone change, if applicable
Make a copy of the information flow

The menu for an expanded information flow additionally allows the planner to:
Edit the information flow elements
Make a copy of this flow
Add the information need (if flow is a receive) or capability (if flow is a send) implied by this flow (duplicate flow)
Add a new, ad hoc issue about the information flow
Add a copied attachment to the information flow documentation, if applicable
Remove the information flow
Break the flow into two flows by inserting an undefined, intermediate task in the flow
Break up the flow by removing it and adding the information capability of the source task in implied (if not already defined) plus, and by adding information need of the target task it implied (also if not already defined)

figure.title: Information flow menus for collapsed and expanded edit forms

section.title: Plan definition panel
section.para: The plan definition panel is opened by selecting the item “About Plan” in the top “Show” menu.

Planners use the plan definition panel's details view to change the name of a plan, give it a description, define phases to be applied to events, localize the plan, attach documents to it, and add ad hoc issues about the plan as a whole.
The "Show" menu of the plan definition panel gives access to other views on the plan, namely:

listitem.para: A list of all events referenced in the plan, with the ability to declare certain events as "incidents" (i.e., outside events not expected to be caused by planned tasks)
The list of all secrecy classifications (also referenced in the plan), with the ability to add and edit secrecy classifications
The list of all organizations within the scope of the IS plan, where a planner can indicate if an organization is expected to be assigned planned tasks
A visualization and analysis of how all segments interrelate
A visual exploration tool of assignments and commitments (IS procedures) computed from the plan
A searchable who's who of all participating agents
A searchable list of all issues anywhere in the plan
A searchable list of all document attachments
An index of all named plan elements (tasks, flows, entities, etc.)
An overall evaluation of the plan with issues metrics
A list of all registered users and their identification with agents in the plan (participations)
A mechanism for voting to release the current development version of the plan into production

section.para: In the All events view, a planner can add events to the scope of the plan. A planner can mark an event as an incident if it is caused outside of the plan and not as an outcome of a planned task. There is always at least one event defined in a plan. Unmarking as incident an event that is not defined and is not referenced anywhere in the plan removes it from the plan.

In the Secrecy classification view, a planner can view all defined secrecy classifications that can be used to qualify elements of information (classification), transmission media (security), and agents (security clearances). Classifications can be reordered, references to a classification can be listed, unreferenced classifications can be removed, and new classification systems and classifications added.

In the All organizations view, a planner can see all organizations within the scope of the IS plan and add new ones with expectations that they be assigned tasks. AN issue is raised if an organization explicitly added to the scope of the IS plan is assigned no task.

figure.title: Plan definition panel - all organizations - scope

section.para: A network view of all interorganization sharing commitments is available to explore the sharing commitments implicit in a plan that crosses organizational boundaries.

figure.title: Plan definition panel - all organizations - network

section.para: In the All segments view, planners can look at a diagram of all segments in the plan. The segments can be grouped by phase or by event. Planners can browse all cross-segment sharing flows as well as all tasks in one segment that start or terminate (the event phase of) another segment.

The Procedure map view lets planners visualize and explore the assignments and commitments implicit in the flow maps. Remember that task assignments and information sharing commitments are implicit in a plan and are computed by Channels by matching known agents with task assignee specifications, and by applying the sharing restrictions set on flows that connect tasks to agents. In other words, assignments and commitments (IS procedures) are the result of applying an environment (known agents employed by known organizations) to an informations sharing model (specifications of tasks and flows).

Because full procedure maps can quickly become quite large and unwieldy, the Procedures map view allows planner to manage this complexity by:
Focusing on the assignments and commitments of (actual) agents or organizations (as an aggregate of employed agents)
Looking at the procedures from a single segment or the entire plan
Aggregating the assignments of those who commit to share with the agent or organization in focus by
type of organization
type of organization and role
organization (actual)
organization and role
In the Who's who view, planners can search a list of all agents known to the plan, and see their responsibilities.
In the All issues view, planners can sort, filter, and browse all issues currently detected in or manually added to the plan. Surveys on individual issues can be created or accessed from this view.
In the Bibliography view, planners browse and can access all the documents that are attached to plan elements.
In the Index view, planners can find, filter, sort, and navigate to all named plan elements.

Entities can be categorized by entity types (agents are categorized by agent types, role are categorized by other roles, etc.). The All types view shows planners the typologies implied by the categorizations of entities.
The tags defined and used in a plan are consolidated in the All tags view where a planner can find what tags are used in a plan and what elements are tagged by a given tag.
The Evaluation view gives a summary evaluation of the plan's fitness by providing metrics about validity, completeness, and robustness issues.

The Participations view lists all registered users and the identity of the agent, if any, that is associated with each user. The planner can make or change these associations as well as update the contact information a participant inherits from the associated agent. A user who is not associated with an agent does not have information sharing guidelines.

The Versions view is where planners vote to move the development version of the plan into production. Note that only an administrator can actually move a development version into production from within the Administrator page.
The actions menu of the plan definition panel enables the planner to undo/redo past changes, send messages about the current plan version, and add issues about the plan as a whole.

section.title: Segment definition panel
section.para: Planners can edit the scope, name and description of a segment. A segment's definition panel is accessed by selecting “About plan segment” from the “Show” menu in the segment bar, or by clicking on the name of the segment also in the segment bar.

This opens the Details view in the segment definition panel. There, the segment can be renamed, and the phase and event it references can be changed as well as the event context, if any. The event can be given the minimum rating (low, medium, high, or highest) at which the tasks and flows in the segment apply. As with any other kind of plan element, reference and policy documents can be attached to a segment, and ad hoc issues can be added.

The "Show" menu in the segment definition panel gives access to views other than the default Details view, namely:
Goals view - to view and edit the goals of the segment
Organizations view - to view the organizations involved in this segment and the sharing commitments between them
Map view - to locate segment tasks on a Google map

The segment is further defined by identifying and describing a set of goals that relate to the event phase addressed by the segment. Goals can be risks to be mitigated or gains to be made. These goals are expected to be realized by tasks in the segment. A segment is expected to have at least one goal.

The Goals view of a segment lets planners define the goals of organizations that are in scope for this segment. Goals can be added and removed. The goal of an organization would be to mitigate a risk or to make a gain. A goal is defined in terms of:
A type picked from a taxonomy of risks or gains, an importance (minor, major, severe, or extreme for risks; low, medium, high, or very high for gains)
The identity of the organization (either an actual organization or a type of organization)
Whether the goal goes away when the event phase covered by the segment terminates
The tasks that mitigate a given risk or achieve a goal in scope can be listed, sorted and navigated to.
The Map view opens a window with a Google map showing all tasks in the segment that specify geo-locatable locations. The geomapping of elements is available whenever applicable throughout Channels.

figure.title: Google map of located tasks in a segment

section.para: The Actions menu of the segment definition panel enables the planner to undo/redo past changes, send messages about the segment, and add issues about the segment as a whole.

section.title: Entity profile panels
section.para: A new entity (an agent, role, organization, place, event, phase, or transmission medium) is automatically created when it is first referenced by name. Channels requires that all entities of a given kind be assigned unique names (John Smith, John Smith (1), John Smith (2), etc.).

The definitions of plan elements can reference both actual entities (ACME Corporation, Peter Sanchez, Morristown NJ) and types of entities (Corporation, Certified Emergency Technician, City). An entity is categorized by listing the names of entity types. An entity can only be categorized with entity types of its own kind (Warehouse A can be categorized as a building but not as a senior executive). The profiles of actual entities and entity types can be edited.
A profile panel for an entity, actual or type, can be opened from wherever the entity is referenced by name, be it in the specification of a task, in the definition of a segment, in an index, etc.

figure.title: Opening entity profiles from a task panel
Accessing entity profiles from the plan index or a reference index

section.para:
As a rule, entity profile panels have these views:
A Details view where entity attributes are edited
A Network view, where applicable, showing how the entity relates to other entities of the same kind
A Map view, where applicable, showing in a separate window where the entity is located
An Issues view where issues that relate to the entity are collected

An entity profile panel opens by default in the Details view. The Details view contains a form for editing the attributes of an entity. All entity profiles, whether they are actual or types, are defined by:

listitem.para: A unique name
A description (free text)
Tags
A categorization (a list of entity types of the same kind)
Document attachments

section.para:
In addition, an entity profile includes:
Some analytical content that relates to the entity
An index of all references to the entity, and matches with the entity, if the entity is a type
A list of all issues about the entity itself or that relate to the entity
A filterable collection of all other entities that relate to the entity
Each kind of entity has additional, specific attributes and these are reflected in the Details view for each kind of entity.
The Network view in the entity profile panel is available for agents, roles, and organizations. It shows how such entities have information sharing commitments with others of the same kind.
If the profiled entity is geo-locatable, a Map view shows where it is located in a different window. A Map view is available for organizations, events, and, of course, places.
An Issues view can show not only issues about the entity, but issues that relate to it. It is available for all kinds of entities.

The Actions menu in profile panels allows planners to:
Undo the planner's last change, if possible
Redo the last undone change, if possible
Send a message about the profiled entity
Add an attachment copied from another plan element, if any
Add an ad hoc issue to the profiled entity

section.title: Role profile panel
section.para: Roles are always entity types, so there's only one kind of profile panel for roles. The edit form in the Details view is a simple one because the profile of a role only has those attributes that are common to all entities.

figure.title: Role profile panel - Details view - analytical content expanded

section.para: The Network view shows how agents, aggregated in the profiled role, have sharing commitments with agents in other roles, also aggregated. The role-playing agents and their sharing commitments aggregated in the visualization are separated out in the sortable, filterable, pageable table underneath the diagram.
The Issues view collects issues about or related to the role and presents them in a filterable, sortable, pageable table. Planners can control which issues are displayed.

section.title: Organization profile panel
section.para: A planner profiling an actual organization can define its mission and give its location, contact information, and parent organization.

A planner can declare that it would be an issue should the profiled organizations have a sharing commitment with one another that is not covered by an agreement. A planner can also declare that it would be an issue should there be a role assigned by the organization in the plan for which there is no known agent.

A planner can add agents to an organization's membership/employment roster by naming the agent (required), the agent's role (required), jurisdiction (optional), title (optional), and supervisor agent (optional). Alternately, the planner can confirm memberships that are already implied by task specifications (a task definition can identify an agent by name in a role within a jurisdiction for an organization).

figure.title: Organization profile panel - Details view - jobs

section.para: Jobs can also be added to an organization by transferring them, or copying them, from another organization.

figure.title: Organization profile panel - Details view - transferring jobs

section.para: Organizations with parent organizations form hierarchical structures that can be visualized as org charts.

figure.title: Organization profile panel - Details view - org chart

section.para: Inter-organizational sharing commitments are commitments between agents acting on behalf of different organizations. A sharing agreement may or may not exist for a sharing commitment that crosses organizational boundaries. It is an issue if an inter-organizational sharing commitment is unconfirmed when it is required by the committing organization. When viewing an organization, a planner can see the sharing commitments the organization makes with other organizations and confirm whether each commitment is covered or not by an agreement. A planner can attach documents of type MOU (Memorandum of Understanding) to confirmed sharing agreements. A sharing agreement not documented by a Memorandum of Understanding is an issue.

figure.title: Organization profile panel - Details view - sharing agreements

section.para: The task assignments and sharing commitments of the organization can be expanded at the bottom of the view. This is followed by an index of plan elements referencing the organization, and by issues about the organization itself, if any.

figure.title: Organization profile panel - Details view - expanded analytical content

section.para: The Details view of an organization type is much simpler than that of an actual organization.

figure.title: Organization type profile panel - Details view

section.para: In addition to the Details view, profile panels for organizations also provide a Network view, Map view (not shown), and Issues view.

figure.title: Organization type profile panel - Network view
Organization type profile panel - Issues view

section.title: Agent profile
section.para: The profile attributes specific to an actual agent are:

listitem.para: Whether or not the agent is an archetype or a placeholder or neither
Whether the agent is a system or a person
The agent's contact information (transmission media with addresses/endpoints where applicable)
The agent's availability
The agent's security clearances (as secrecy classification levels)

section.para: In addition to a profile attributes edit form, the Details view of an agent lists the roles played by the agent, the agent's task assignments and sharing commitments (if expanded), all references to the agent (indexed), and all issues detected or reported specifically about the agent.
An agent type has a simpler profile than an actual agent with only typical availability as an agent-specific entity attribute.

figure.title: Agent type profile panel - Details view

section.para: The agent profile panel includes Network, Map, and Issues views.

figure.title: Agent type profile panel - Network view
Agent type profile panel - Issues view

section.title: Place profile panel
section.para: When profiling an actual place, a planner can identify what other place, if any, contains it. A planner can also give the place a street address, postal code, and a geoname (the name of a town, state, mountain, lake etc.). If the geoname is ambiguous, more specific geonames are offered for confirmation.
When profiling a type of place, a planner can specify that actual places of this type must:

listitem.para: Be inside
the plan's locale
the location of an event in the plan's scope
or another actual or type of place
Contain
the plan's locale
the location of an event in the plan's scope
or another actual or type of place

figure.title: Place type profile panel - Details view

section.para: There is of course a Map view for actual place entities, and an Issues view for both actual places and place types.

section.title: Transmission medium profile panel
section.para: When editing a transmission medium, a planner can set the transmission mode to either unicast (one -to-one), multicast (one-to-many), or broadcast (one-to-any), unless the mode of this medium is already implied by that of another medium categorizing it.

The address pattern is a “regular expression” that constrains the form an “address” can take for this medium (see http://www.regular- expressions.info/ for a tutorial on regular expressions). An empty pattern imposes no constraint on the value of an address/endpoint.

A planner can identify what media this a transmission medium can interface with (delegates to) as it carries out transmissions from sender to receiver. For example, a notification system would interface with phone, email, pager, etc.

Finally, a planner can describe the security of the transmission medium in terms of secrecy classifications. Qualifying a medium as “US Gov/Top Secret” means that Top Secret information can be transmitted securely over this medium.
Keep in mind that all transmission media are types; there is no such thing in ISP as an "actual" transmission medium.

figure.title: Transmission medium profile panel - Details view

section.para: The profile panel for transmission media have an Issues view.

figure.title: Transmission medium profile panel - Issues view

section.title: Event profile panel
section.para: An event in ISP is always an entity type (all events in ISP are anticipated, none are actual). A planner can set the location (actual or type) where actual events of this type would occur. A planner can also indicate whether or not this type of event can terminate on its own, that is, without the intervention of agents.
The event profile panel has a Map and Issues views.

section.title: Phase profile panel
section.para: Planners can add any number of phases to the scope of a plan. In addition to setting generic entity attributes (name, description, classification), a planner indicates whether a phase is before an event (pre-event), during an event (co-event), or after an event (post-event).
The phase profile panel also has an Issues view to show all issues that relate to a profiled phase.

section.title: Task assignments and sharing commitments panels
section.para: Recall that a task can identity one assignee explicitly as an actual agent, but that tasks assignees are usually specified in terms of types of agents, roles, jurisdictions (actual or types of places), and organizations (types or actual). A task thus defined could be assigned to more than one agent. Channels looks up all agents known to a plan to determine which ones are to be assigned to the task.
A planner can look up the list of known agents that are implicitly or explicitly assigned to the task (the task assignments).

Agents are implicitly bound by sharing commitments when they are assigned to tasks that are sources of shared information, subject to sharing restrictions. All agents assigned to the "source" task have sharing commitments with all agents assigned to the "recipient" task, except:

listitem.para: If the sharing flow is prohibited
If a restriction does not apply - For example, the source and beneficiary must be in the same organization or location, or the beneficiary must be the source's supervisor, etc.

section.para: A planner can look up the list of sharing commitments inferred by an information flow.

figure.title: Accessing information sharing commitments for a flow
Information sharing commitments for a flow

section.title: Task overrides panel
section.para: A task can be defined in such a way as to be a more specific case of another task, in effect overriding it. An overridden task can not be assigned any of the agents assigned to the overriding task. This allows planners to model exceptions and special cases in an IS plan.
When a task is overridden or overrides another, planners can bring up an overrides panel for that task.

figure.title: Access to the task overrides panel
Task overrides panel showing an overridden task
Task overrides panel showing an overriding task

section.title: Failure impact analysis panel
section.para: Planners can visualize what might happen should an agent fail completely at an assigned task or should an agent break a commitment to share information. The consequences could be a number of downstream tasks failing, leading to gains unachieved or risks unmitigated.

For the sake of analysis, it is assumed that a failure is always complete; a failed task does not produce any information that may be required by others, and a failed information flow does not transfer any information whatsoever.
A failure can cause a cascade of task failures if tasks directly or indirectly depend critically on, or are triggered by, information that fails to be produced or to be shared.

Not all sharing failures matter. If an information flow is not critical to a task or does not trigger it, then its failure does not propagate to other tasks. Furthermore, if the target of a flow can get the same information via another, non-failing flow, then the failure of the flow may not matter. Finally, if information produced by an agent is necessarily consumed by the same agent then, clearly, failure to share is meaningless.

Failure analysis only concerns itself with the failure of useful tasks. A useful task is one that achieves goals or one that produces information that triggers, terminates or is critical to another task that is itself useful. (Useless tasks are flagged as issues.)
Note that a task will terminate a risk if it causes a segment to end and if the risk is said to terminate with the segment.

A planner does “what-if” failure analysis by selecting a task or an information flow (“send” or “receive”) and then looking at the consequences should it fail. The planner can take a pessimistic outlook and assume that all redundant information flows would also fail, no matter what.

The result of the analysis is a cascade of failures visualized as a directed graph of information flows, tasks, gains, and risks. Risks that would otherwise be mitigated or terminated by failed tasks are shown as color-coded flags. Red is for extreme risks, orange is for severe risks, yellow for major risks, and blue for minor risks. Risks that would normally be mitigated by successful tasks are shown connected to these tasks. Risks that would be terminated, should a segment end, are shown connected to red stop lights. Each stop light is itself connected to a failed task that would normally end the segment.
Missed gains are shown as stars and are similarly color-coded by importance, with red for very high, orange for high, yellow for medium, and blue for low.

In addition to the visual map, a tabular list of failed, goal-achieving tasks (the failures that matter) is compiled and presented. The table is paginated and the columns (failing task, segment, impact, goal, magnitude of the loss, and organization impacted) can be sorted.

figure.title: Accessing the failure impact analysis on a task
Failure impacts of a failed task

section.para: Failure analysis crosses segment boundaries. A failed task in one segment can cause tasks to fail in other segments. Tasks, flows, and goals in segments other than the selected segment are put in blue-gray boxes.
The impacts of the failure of a specific flow can also be shown in a panel.

figure.title: Accessing the failure impact analysis on a flow
Failure impacts of a failed flow

section.title: Information dissemination analysis panel
section.para: If planners systematically indicate how elements of information flowing out of a task relate to elements of information flowing into a task, Channels becomes able to track the planned dissemination of individual elements of information. Dissemination tracking can be done forward (where does an element of information go?) and backward (where does an element of information come from?).

A dissemination panel can be opened from a task, offering a choice of all elements received or sent by the task, or it can be opened from a flow, restricting the choice to the elements shared via the flow.

Dissemination tracking from a task gives the option of looking at the sources as well as at the targets of individual elements of information. A dissemination panel opened on a "receive" flow only tracks sources, and a dissemination panel opened on a "send" flow only tracks targets.

figure.title: Access to dissemination panel from a task

section.para: Dissemination tracking is visualized as element flows. A table shows all source or target tasks, together with the transformations on the element from a source, or the cumulated transformations when reaching a target. The timeliness of the disseminations are indicated in the table. Untimely disseminations are indicated in red.

figure.title: Dissemination of an element from sources
Dissemination of an element to targets

section.title: Surveys panel
section.para: Planners can survey other planners and participants in the current plan about the remediation of issues detected by Channels or manually entered by planners.
Channels interfaces with the SurveyGizmo Web service to create, launch, and retire surveys, and to collect responses.
The content of a survey is automatically taken from the issue's description.

section.title: Assignments and Commitments Page
section.para: The assignments and commitments page enables planners to explore the task assignments and information sharing commitments (IS procedures) computed by Channels for a plan.
A planner first enters focus and summarization parameters for the generation of the visualization of tasks assignments and information sharing commitments. A planner then requests the visualization.

The focus parameters are:
A choice of viewing the IS procedures generated from one segment or from the entire plan
The identity of the agent or organization (taken as an aggregate of agents) for which to generate IS procedures

The summarization parameter determines how to aggregate, if at all, the task assignments of those other than the focused-on agent or organization. The choices are:
By organization - aggregate task assignments by organizations
By organization and role- aggregate task assignments by roles in organizations
By type of organization- aggregate task assignments by type of organization
By type of organization and role- aggregate task assignments by roles in types of organization
Don't summarize - show the task assignments of individual agents

Summarizing by type of organization and for a single segment minimizes the size of the visualization. Requesting to see the procedures for the entire plan and without summarization can yield very large visualizations that might take a while to display.

A planner can also request a drill-down report view of all (and only) the task assignments and sharing commitments shown in the visualization. At the top level of the report, all triggers for assigned tasks are listed and organized by events, by phases, and by how they are triggered (notification, request, automatically). The lists are initially collapsed and can be expanded.
A planner clicks on the trigger of an assigned task to open a view on the task. The Task view lists the information received and sent by the task's assignees.

figure.title: Assignments and commitments report view - task details

section.para: Clicking on the timing requirements of an incoming or outgoing flow opens the Flow view.

figure.title: Assignments and commitments report view - flow details

section.title: Issues Summary Page
section.para: Channels summarizes all outstanding issues detected in and manually added to a plan in a page accessible from the Home page. The issues summary page provides metrics about the severities of the three overall types of issues (robustness, completeness, and validity), and about each kind of issue found in the plan. (Channels detects more than 90 different kinds of issues.)

section.title: Participants List Page
section.para: Planners access the participants list page from the Home page and use it to access the IS guideline pages of any participant or any agent. (A participant is a user associated with an agent in the plan.)

section.title: IS Guidelines Page
section.para: Channels produces, on demand, personalized information sharing guidelines in report format for each participant.

A participant accesses his/her IS guidelines directly from the Home page. A planner accesses the IS guidelines of a participant (or an agent) indirectly from the participants list which is accessible from the Home page.

The IS guidelines report organizes a participant's IS procedures generated from the plan by situations (relevant event phases, possibly in the context of past or present events) and connects the IS procedures with related contact information. The IS guidelines are presented in a single HTML document suitable for browsing and printing.

section.title: Information needs report
section.para: Channels produces, on demand, a report on the information needs of each participant.

A participant accesses his/her information needs report directly from the Home page. A planner accesses the information needs report of a participant (or an agent) indirectly from the participants list which is accessible from the Home page.

figure.title: Accessing the information needs report of participants

section.para: The report lists the information needed by an agent to execute his/her assigned tasks in an IS plan. The information needs are organized by the tasks that require the information, and the tasks are themselves organized by the situations (relevant event phases, possibly in the context of past or present events) in which they are executed.

The degree to which information needs are satisfied (fully, somewhat or not at all) is indicated. The analysis is done at the level of individual elements of information. The information needs report is a single HTML document suitable for browsing and printing.

section.title: Help and Feedback
section.para: A planner accesses the help documentation by pressing on the Help button.
Feedback buttons appear in the Home page, in the Help page, in IS guidelines, and in the information needs report. Clicking on a feedback button opens a feedback panel.

section.title: Logging Out of Channels
section.para: A planner signs out to terminate a Channels session. Sign out buttons are available from the Home page as well as other pages.
Any edit locks still held by a planner are automatically released. The user is then presented with a login page.

chapter.title: The ISP Method
chapter.para: Channels enables information sharing planners to apply the ISP Method, an incremental and nonlinear process for building information sharing plans from which useful analytics and robust information sharing procedures can be generated.

IS analytics enable planners to better understand the consequences and weaknesses of a plan while IS procedures enable participating organizations to more reliably fulfill their missions through information sharing, before, during, and/or after one or more events of significance.

The ISP Method defines:
The conceptual building blocks of a plan (see previous chapter)
The activities by which a plan is built, with prerequisites, steps, and outcomes
Strategies for moving a plan to completion
Issues that may keep a plan from being deemed valid, complete, and robust

section.title: ISP Method and ISP Process
section.para: The ISP Method is encompassed by the ISP Process. The ISP Process includes the ISP Method and adds best practices for the successful promotion, definition, initiation, implementation, and review of information sharing planning projects. The ISP Process, other than its significance to the ISP Method, is outside the scope of this document.

figure.title: Where the ISP Method fits within the ISP Process

section.para: The ISP Method is defined in terms of the ISP concepts covered earlier and of ISP Method activities (activities for short). These activities should not be confused with ISP Process best practices. For example, a ISP best practice might help planners decide what the scope an IS plan should be, whereas a plan scoping activity would indicate any prerequisite activities, prescribe how to capture the scope of a plan (once decided upon), and indicate what further activities could follow up changes to the scope.

section.title: Building an Information Sharing Plan
section.para: An IS plan is built by information sharing planners (planners) who carry out activities defined in the ISP Method in order to move the plan toward completion and also increase its value.

section.title: Overview of the ISP Method activities
section.para: Activities alter the scope of an IS plan, bring the plan closer to completion, or improve the quality and value of the IS procedures generated from the plan.

Activities are organized into four groups:
Scoping an IS plan initiates the building of an IS plan, but these activities can also be reapplied at any time, whenever the scope needs to change.
Specifying IS procedures by defining tasks and information flows from which the procedures are computed
Profiling referenced entitites includ types of events, roles, phases and transmission media, or actual or types of organizations, places, and agents
Improving the IS plan by making it more manageable, robust, complete, and reusable

There is no fixed, prescribed order to the execution of ISP Method activities. Scope can be modified at any time while an IS plan is being built. Tasks and information flows can also be added, removed, or modified at any point in time. Entities can be profiled as soon they are mentioned by name and they can be named at any time. An IS Plan can and should be improved early and often in order to keep it as manageable and as valuable as possible.

section.title: Issues
section.para: The ISP Method defines a relatively large number (90+) of issues that can be detected in an IS plan. They are categorized as:

listitem.para: Validity issues - something is incorrectly specified or defined
Completeness issues - something is apparently missing
Robustness issues - something makes the plan inherently failure-prone

figure.title: Summary of issues found in an IS plan

section.para: An issue can be about the IS plan as a whole, or about a segment, a task, a flow, an entity, or any other kind of plan element.

An issue can be assigned a severity of minor, major, severe, or extreme. The severity of an issue is either preset according to the kind of issue (for example, an information flow without elements of information is always a major issue), or computed by determining the most severe risk mitigation or gain capture that could be foiled by a cascade of failures caused by the issue.
An issue comes with one or more alternate options for its remediation. A planner can elect to launch a survey to gather opinions on how to remediate an issue.
All types of issues defined in the ISP Method can be detected by Channels. Some issue detections are “best guesses” and can be waived by planners if they are deemed to be false positives.

figure.title: Issues detected on a flow that can be waived

section.para: Planners can report ad hoc issues that are not in the list of 90+ predefined kinds of ISP issues Issues reported by planners will typically be domain-specific (all of the ISP issue types are domain-agnostic).

figure.title: Ad hoc issue reported by a planner about a task, with remediation options

section.para: A complete list of detectable ISP issues can be found in the Appendix.

section.title: Moving an IS plan to completion
section.para: When is an IS plan complete? There is really no satisfactory answer to this question. Because one could always increase the scope of a plan, a more useful question would be: Given its current scope, is there something clearly missing from a plan? If the answer is no, then the plan can be deemed “complete.”

Knowing whether the scope of an IS plan is properly set requires knowing the domains of human endeavor involved and being able to identify the organizations that ought to participate in the plan. Absent this knowledge, software can only examine an IS plan to detect what is inherently missing from it.

Nothing is inherently missing from a plan if:
Each phase of each event in scope is addressed by at least one segment of the plan.
An event is not self-terminating; each segment addressing a co-event phase for that event has at least one task that terminates the segment.
Each segment has at least one defined goal.
Each goal listed in a segment is achieved by at least one task within that segment.
Each participating organization and agent within the scope of the plan is assigned at least one task.
Each task is assigned to at least one agent.
Each information sharing flow generates at least one information sharing commitment.
Each task is useful in that it directly achieves a goal, or directly or indirectly enables a task that does.
Each referenced role in an organization is assigned to at least one member agent (if required).
Each inter-organizational information sharing commitment is covered by a sharing agreement documented by a Memorandum of Understanding (if required).
The scope of an IS plan can be changed even after it is deemed complete. Tasks, flows, and entities that do not contribute to completing a plan are considered redundant. Redundant tasks, flows, or entities should be removed from a plan. If the scope of a plan is reduced, some elements of a plan may become redundant as a result.
The ISP Method proposes three distinct strategies for driving an IS plan toward completion:

listitem.para: Goal-driven strategy - Add goal-achieving tasks and work backward to satisfy their information needs.
Effect-driven strategy - Add tasks that execute at the onset of event phases and work forward by connecting tasks with outgoing flows.
Issue-driven strategy - Resolve or waive outstanding issues until none remains.

section.para: Planners usually use of all three strategies opportunistically when building an IS plan.

section.title: Goal-driven strategy
section.para: Planners look at each organizational goal attached to a phase of an anticipated event, add tasks that achieve it, and add the information needs of each of these tasks. They then add tasks that produce the needed information and connect the tasks with information flows. This process continues until all goals are addressed by tasks, and all task information needs are satisfied.
Step 1 - Select a goal within a segment

figure.title: A risk mitigation goal in a segment

section.para: Step 2 - Add a task that achieves the goal

figure.title: Adding a task that mitigates the risk

section.para: Step 3 - Specify the information needs of the task

figure.title: Defining the information needs of the risk-mitigating task

section.para: Step 4 - Add a flow-connected task to satisfy a need

figure.title: A task and flow are added to satisfy an information need

section.para: Systematic use of a goal-driven strategy guarantees that all tasks and flows, and consequently the IS procedures generated from them, are within the scope of the IS plan, because all tasks and flows contribute directly or indirectly to addressing identified goals. However, this strategy alone does not guarantee that tasks triggered by the start of event phases will be included. In other words, this "working from the end" strategy does not guarantee that it will reach all starting points.

section.title: Effect-driven strategy
section.para: Planners start with the onset of an event phase, add tasks that are either directly started by it or are ongoing at the onset. They then add the information flows from these tasks to other tasks that are triggered or terminated by the shared information. Planners indicate whether tasks initiate or terminate events. This process continues until no task gets triggered or terminated by information produced by specified tasks, and all event phases are covered.
Step 1 - Select an event phase and a segment focusing on it

figure.title: Segment created to cover an event phase

section.para: Step 2 - Add a task that is ongoing at the onset of the event phase or starts with it

figure.title: Task added that starts with the event phase

section.para: Step 3- Add a flow from task to a task it triggers or terminates

figure.title: Task added triggered by flow from started task

section.para: Systematic use of an effect-driven strategy is akin to telling a story from beginning to end, and thus may feel more natural to many planners. However some tasks and flows added using this strategy might not necessarily contribute directly or indirectly to achieving identified goals. In other words, a "starting from the beginning" strategy does not guarantee that it will reach all required end points.

section.title: Issue-driven strategy
section.para: When using an issue-driven strategy, planners scan the list of outstanding issues and determine which ones to either waive or resolve. Issues of validity ought to be dealt with first, followed by issues of completeness and then issues of robustness. Usually, everything else being equal, issues of higher severity should be given higher priority for remediation.

A planner selects a high-priority issue and either waives it (if applicable) or applies one of the recommended remediations, possibly after having queried other planners and/or participants. The process is repeated until no unwaived issue remains.
Step 1- Scan and prioritize outstanding issues

section.para: Step 2- Select issue

The task missing with issue is navigated to

section.para: Step 3- Choose remediation, possibly by surveying other planners

figure.title: A survey is about to be launched about remediating the issue
Issue remediation survey to be launched

figure.title: The issue is resolved by connecting the task with an "on failure" flow

section.para: A plan with no outstanding, “unwaived” issues means that Channels and the planners considers the plan to be valid, complete, and robust. Because Channels has no domain knowledge (for example, it knows nothing about public health or mergers and acquisitions, etc.), domain-dependent issues will not be detected by Channels. Planners must use their own domain knowledge to determine if the IS plan has issues that lie outside the range of automatically detected issues.

section.title: Activities
section.para: An ISP Method activity is carried out by an IS planner either to correct a mistake in the definition of an IS plan, bring the plan closer to completion, or make it more robust.

An activity is composed of a number of steps, all of which may be optional, often to be carried out in no particular order. Most activities can be undone (for example, a task added to the IS plan can be later removed). Prerequisites for an activity, if there are any, are usually few and commonsensical. For example, a task in a segment cannot be specified unless the segment is already defined.
Note that for each "Add ..." activity there is usually an implied and related "Remove ..." and "Modify ..." activity. For example, "Add task" implies "Remove task" and "Modify task".
Prior to applying any activity, it is assumed that:

listitem.para: An IS plan has been created and given a unique identifier (the identifier is not the name of the plan; it is universally unique and cannot be changed once the plan has been created)
Users have been authorized as planners
A default segment is created for a default phase of a default incident event (Channels does it automatically)

section.para: As stated earlier, activities fall under scoping a plan, specifying information sharing procedures, profiling entities, or improving a plan.

section.title: Scoping a plan
section.para: The activities that modify the scope of an IS plan are:

listitem.para: Localizing the IS plan
Identifying an event as an incident
Identifying a planned phase
Identifying a participating organization
Identifying a participating agent
Adding a segment
Adding an organizational goal
Adding a secrecy classification system

section.title: Localizing the IS plan
section.para: Localizing an IS plan sets the locale or type of locale where the plan applies. This allows other places to be defined relative to the plan's locale, thus making easy to "move the plan" to a different locale (for example, from Philadelphia, PA to New York, NY). Localizing a plan is optional.

listitem.para: The plan was created
Set the locale of the plan either as an actual place or as a type of place.
Place types (other than the plan's locale and places it is defined by) can be defined relative to the plan's locale.

figure.title: Setting the plan's locale to a type of place

section.para: A plan's locale need not be set. If it is set, then place types within the plan can be defined to be within or containing the plan's locale (whatever it may be). Of course, a place identified as the plan's locale can not be defined relative to the plan's locale, either directly or indirectly through the definition of its place categories, containing places, or contained places. (See "Profiling a place").

section.title: Identifying an event as an incident
section.para: The scope of an IS plan is largely set by identifying the types of anticipated events that are of concern. An event is considered an "incident" if it is unplanned (no task within the plan is expected to cause it). An IS plan always has at least one incident event within its scope. When an IS plan is created, an "unnamed" event is put in its list of incidents.

section.title: Identifying a planned phase
section.para: When an IS plan is created, Channels automatically defines a "co-event" phase and calls it "Responding." If planners want to also plan for the "before" or "after" of events, they need to add them to the scope of the plan by naming them in the Details view of the plan definition panel. Planners can also rename the default "Responding" phase to anything they want. A phase that is not referenced anywhere, other than in the plan's Details view, can be removed from the scope.

section.title: Identifying a participating organization
section.para: An actual organization (as opposed to a type of organization) is implicitly added to the scope of an IS plan any time it is referenced by name in the definition of a task or of some other plan element. A planner can also make an actual organization part of the scope of a plan by adding it directly to the list of all organizations in the scope of the plan.

Identify an actual organization in a task definition and add the expectation that it will be assigned tasks
Or, add an actual organization explicitly to the scope of the plan
The organization remains durably in the scope of the plan (even if it not referenced in any task definition).
An issue is raised if no member of the organization is assigned at least one task.
The organization can be profiled.
Participating agents for this organization can be identified.

figure.title: Implicitly adding an actual organization to the scope
Putting an organization permanently in the scope of the plan by setting expectation of participation
Directly adding an organization permanently to the scope of the plan

section.para: Organizations added to the scope of the plan by any method other than by directly adding them to the list of participating organizations will be removed from the scope if they are no longer referenced within the plan. By adding an organization to the list, it remains in the scope of the plan even if the organization is not referenced by name in any task definition (or in another organization's profile). An organization already referenced in the plan can be added durably to the scope by "adding expectations" that it is being assigned tasks. A planner can later remove such expectations.

section.title: Identifying a participating agent
section.para: The scope of an IS plan includes not only participating organizations but also participating agents, that is, agents as role-playing members of organizations that can be assigned to tasks. Agents "employed by organizations" are added to the scope implicitly from the definitions of tasks, or explicitly by defining the "jobs" of participating organizations that are relevant to the plan.

Since it is a best practice not to directly identify the assignees of tasks but rather to specify them via their roles in types of organizations, the preferred approach for identifying participating agents is to list them with their jobs in the profiles of participating organizations.

An agent is further identified by associating one or more users to it. The meaning of associating a user to an actual agent depends on whether the agent is designated as an archetype, a placeholder, or (the default) a normal agent.

An archetype agent captures the notion of a group of anonymous and indistinguishable agents (same contact info, same roles in the same organizations). An "ACME Call Center Agent" would be an archetype playing the role of "Call Center Agent" for the organization "ACME" and with some 1-800 number as its communication channel. Any number of Channels users can be associated with an archetype. These users all receive the IS guidelines of their associated archetype.

A placeholder agent is an agent whose identity is to be given via their associations with users. A placeholder agent can be given default contact information that the associated user(s) can override and add to. A placeholder agent can be restricted to only one associated user or can be open to associations with many users. A user associated with a placeholder agent gets the IS guidelines of that agent, with the user's contact info substitutions/additions.

The default kind of actual agent directly identifies the person or system and provides contact information as part of the profile. Only one user can be associated by planners with a normal, actual agent. The full name of the user and of the agent are expected to match (an issue is raised if not). The associated user gets the agent's IS guidelines. It is an ISP best practice to define agents, as much as possible, either as archetypes or as placeholders.

Or, add the agent with job definition to the profile of the participating organization the agent is a member of (preferred).
Set the agent as either normal (the default), an archetype, or a placeholder (See Profiling Activities - Profile an agent).
Associate one or more users with the agent.
The agent is automatically assigned to tasks where it matches assignee specifications.
An issue is raised if a participating agent is not assigned to any task.
The agent can be profiled.
Users associated with agents can retrieve their IS guidelines.

section.para: An agent remains durably in the scope of the plan if it has a "confirmed" job listed as part of the profile of a participating organization. An agent's job is not confirmed if it is implied only from the definition of a task. Planners should confirm an agent's job to keep it durably in the scope of a plan.
Planners associate users with agents (and dissociate them) via the participants list accessed from the planner Home page.

section.title: Adding a plan segment
section.para: The information sharing model of an IS plan is composed of segments, each focusing on one phase of one event, possibly in the context of other past or current events. Each segment defines a list of organizational goals to be achieved via flow-connected tasks. Adding a segment contributes to setting the scope of a plan, because doing so is a prerequisite to adding organizational goals that contribute to the scope.

listitem.para: An IS plan is created
Add a new segment to the plan.
Name and optionally describe the segment.
Set the phase of the event in focus and rate its required/"threshold" level (minor, major, high, very high).
Set the past or present events in context.
Organizational goals can be added to the segment.
Tasks and flows can be added to the segment.

figure.title: Identifying phase and event in focus, rating it, and adding contextual events

section.para: When an IS plan is created, it initially contains an untitled segment focusing on the "Responding" phase of the unnamed event. The segment has a single, undefined task and no organizational goals.
A segment can be removed in its entirety, after confirmation. The operation can be undone.

A segment identifies any number of evens as context to the event phase in focus. A segment's context represents what events have occurred or are already occurring when the event phase in focus starts. Events can also be removed from the context.

section.title: Add an organizational goal
section.para: Adding a goal to a segment augments the scope of an IS plan. An organizational goal is either a risk to be mitigated or a gain to be made by an organization (or type of) within the segment where it is listed.

A goal is categorized by choosing from a fixed list of risk or gain types (based on actuarial risk management taxonomies), graded for severity/magnitude, and briefly described with free-form text. Planners can also indicate whether a goal is implicitly achieved with the termination of the segment's event phase (for example, the risk of property damage is terminated when responding to a fire is over, but the risk of litigation is not).

Briefly describe the goal (optional).

section.para: A goal can only be removed from the list if it is not referenced by any task within the segment. References to the goal are shown in the Goals view of the segment definition panel.

section.title: Adding a secrecy classification system
section.para: A secrecy classification system is a named ordered list of classification names (for example, US Government: sensitive, confidential, secret, top secret). Secrecy classifications are used to set agent clearances, communication channels' security, and the classification levels of elements of information. When an IS plan is created, it defines no secrecy classification system. Planners must first define a secrecy classification system before it can be applied.

figure.title: Adding a secrecy classification system and level

section.para: A secrecy classification level can be removed from a secrecy classification system if it is not used anywhere within the plan. Planners can see where a classification level is being used.

section.title: Specifying information sharing procedures
section.para: The IS procedures of an agent (a person or system) are the list of all tasks assigned to the agent, plus all consequent information sharing commitments as computed from an IS plan in which the agent participates. Planners directly set IS procedures. IS procedures are specified by the definitions of tasks and flows and by the profiles of entities (roles, organizations, agents, places, etc.)
The activities that change the set of IS procedures derived from an IS plan are:

listitem.para: Adding a task
Adding a task's information need
Adding a task's information capability
Connecting tasks with an information flow

section.title: Adding a task
section.para:
A planner normally adds a task to a segment either because it
Directly achieves a goal listed in the definition of the segment
Produces information required by goal-achieving tasks
Is triggered by (or is ongoing at) the onset of the phase of the event the segment focuses on.

Categorize the task as:
operations (a task that directly accomplishes the mission of the organization)

direction (a management task tackling operational cohesion and optimization, resource allocation, setting performance targets)
audit (a management task that measures the organization's operational performance)
analysis (a task that examines and makes sense of the organization's external environment)
planning/preparing (a forward-looking task: market research, forward planning, strategy, R&D, etc.)

section.title: Adding a task's information need
section.para: The incoming flows of a task implicitly define satisfied needs for the task. By adding an explicit information need to a task, a planner defines an information requirement of the task that may or may not be satisfied by incoming flows. The planner also indicates that incoming flows partially satisfying or completing this information need are not necessarily the only acceptable sources. Channels looks at the information needs and information capabilities of tasks to uncover missed opportunities for information sharing (see "Satisfy all needs" in the Commands section).

Note that only the explicit information needs of a task are visible across segments and offered as candidate targets for cross-segment flows. (Software types might want to think of information needs and information capabilities as defining the "interfaces of a segment.")

section.title: Connecting tasks with an information flow
section.para: A planner connects two tasks with an information flow to express the requirement that agents executing the source task commit to share information with agents executing the target task, possibly subject to some restrictions. The information is either produced by or acquired for the execution of the source task, and the information is to be used for the execution of the target task. The same flow appears to the source task in its list of "sends" and to the target task in its list of "receives".

A planner connects a source and target task by doing any of the following:
Opening an information capability of the source-to-be task and identifying or creating the target task in the "To task" field. The target task can be created in situ by selecting "Other..." in the list of candidate target tasks and naming a task that does not yet exist within the segment.
If the flow is between tasks in the same segment, the information need is converted into an information flow; to preserve the information need, the planner must duplicate it and set the source on only the copy or the original. If the flow is between tasks in different segments, the information need is preserved when the flow is created.
Opening an information need of the target-to-be task and identifying or creating the source task in the "From task" field. The source task can be created in situ by selecting "Other..." in the list of candidate source tasks and naming a task that does not yet exist within the segment.
If the flow is between tasks in the same segment, the information capability is converted into an information flow; to preserve the information capability, the planner must duplicate it and set the target on only the copy or the original. If the flow is between tasks in different segments, the information capability is preserved when the flow is created.
Selecting a task with at least one information need and executing the "Satisfy all needs" command on it. The task will be connected with all tasks, across all segments, that have matching information capabilities (if not connected already). The information need and all information capabilities are preserved.

Note that tasks in different segments can be connected by an information flow only if both tasks are both already defined and if an information need of one matches an information capability of the other (an unnamed need matches all capabilities and vice-versa).

section.title: Profiling entities
section.para: In ISP, entities encompass the "static elements" in IS plans that can be unambiguously identified and thus uniquely named. ISP entities are events, phases (of events), agents (people or systems), organizations, roles, places, and communication media (phone, email, etc.) Tasks and flows are not entities because they are neither static (they are what agents do) nor are they uniquely named.

Entities are referenced by name in the definitions of a plan, plan segments, tasks, flows, and in the definitions of other entities. An entity is created the first time it is named and is removed when no longer referenced (immediately if its definition is empty).

Entities can be "actual" or "types". An "actual" entity represents a physical reality, whereas a "type of entity" represents a category of entity. "John Doe" would be an actual agent, whereas "Adult" would be a type of agent. "The United Nations" is an actual organization, whereas "International Governing Body" is a type of organization. And so on. Some kinds of entities can only be types in an IS plan, namely events, phases, roles, and communication media. ISP does not deal with actual events, only with types of anticipated events. Roles, phases, and communication media are inherently categories.

Planners can define (profile) an entity as soon as it is first referenced by giving values to some or all of the entity's attributes. All entities, be they types or actual, have a few attributes in common:
Name - set when first referenced and changeable at any time
Description - short, unstructured text
Tags - a list of tags used for ad hoc grouping of plan elements
Categories - a list of same-kind entity types (an agent is categorized by agent types, a role is categorized by other roles, etc.)
Documentation (attached image, reference document, etc.)

Of these common attributes, categories are particularly important. How an agent, role, place, organization, etc. is categorized can have wide-ranging consequences on how tasks, which are typically defined in terms of entity types, are assigned, and thus on what information sharing commitments are computed from an IS plan. A small change in the categorization of an organization or a role can significantly alter the IS procedures implied in an IS plan.

Most kinds of entities have their own idiosyncratic attributes. For example, an actual organization can have a parent organization, an actual agent can have security clearances, a communication medium might delegate transmissions to other media, etc. The Profiling activities of the ISP Method describe what these attributes are and give their meanings.

Entity profiles are accessed in different ways. An entity's profile can be accessed in Channels
From wherever it is named as part of the definition of a plan element
From the plan's index
From analytical content, such as the compilations of references (for example, all references to the role "Manager")
As a rule, when the name of an entity (or of its kind) appears in blue, it is a hyperlink that, when clicked, opens the profile edit form for that entity.

section.title: Improving a plan
section.para: A number of ISP Method activities do not change the scope of an IS plan nor do they add elements to it, but rather are concerned with improving the plan overall. A plan is improved either by better distributing tasks and flows across segments, by generalizing a task's definition to increase the number of agents that are assignable to it, or by making changes to entity typologies that have wide-ranging effects on the generation of IS procedures.
The Channels-supported, plan-improving activities are:

Generalizing a task's definition
Changing the categorization of an entity

section.title: Moving tasks across segments
section.para: An IS plan is a collection of segments, each focusing on a specific situation, namely, one phase of one event, possibly in the context of other current or past events. Segments are usually inter-connected both by flows that connect two tasks in different segments, and by the fact that a task in one segment may trigger the situation that is the focus of another segment.

Each segment addresses one or more risks to or opportunities for organizations (goals) for a given situation. As more goals are added to the scope, more tasks are needed to achieve them and to provide needed information. A segment could grow to become quite large and difficult to manage (the flow maps become oversized, the list of completeness issues for the segment become hard to track, etc.)
A solution is to create a new segment, move to the new segment tasks from the large segment that achieve or help achieve a goal, and then remove the goal from the initial segment.

Channels provides a simple and safe mechanism for moving selected tasks all at once to another segment while keeping them connected with their flows. Goals listed in moved tasks are added as needed to the destination segment. Moving tasks is a reversible (undo-able) change.

section.title: Generalizing a task's definition
section.para: Sometimes the assignees of a task are specified too narrowly in the definition of the task, possibly because an organization is identified by name in the definition, or because the role given is too specific. It can also be the case that an IS plan contains multiple tasks, each with the same name but with different, narrowly defined assignee specifications, that could be replaced by a single task with more broadly specified assignees.

However, when two broadly defined tasks are connected by a flow, many of the implied information sharing commitments may be inappropriate. For example, assignees to both the source and target tasks of a flow may be from different organizations (organization types were used to specify task assignees). If the intent was for task assignees to communicate only with co-workers, then a planner must put in a restriction on the flow stating that sharing commitments are only between agents in the same organization. The alternative is to define multiple source and target tasks, each narrowly assigned to members of only one organization (but otherwise identically named pair-wise), and connect them with flows of the same name.

It is an ISP best practice to avoid as much as possible having multiple tasks of the same name in the same segment, except for purposes of overriding tasks and/or flows (see section on Overriding tasks and flows). Generalizing task assignee specifications combined with flow restrictions can greatly reduce the number of tasks and flows in an IS plan, thus making it more manageable and easier to grow.

section.title: Commands
section.para: Planners carry out ISP activities in Channels by executing Channels commands. Any change to an IS plan is the result of executing a command. Planners execute commands in Channels whenever they create and remove segments; when they add, cut, copy and paste tasks, needs, capabilities and flows; connect tasks with information flows, disconnect them, add an issue, remove a segment, move tasks across segments, add an intermediate to a flow, etc.

Some commands are directly triggered from “actions” menus within the context of a plan, segment, task, flow, or entity. Other commands are triggered by updating fields in edit forms, or by pressing buttons.
Some commands have simple effects (adding a task, for example) but others can be more complex:

listitem.para: “Disintermediate” removes a task that acts as a middleman in a flow
“Intermediate” adds a middleman task to a flow
“Satisfy all needs” automatically connects information needs of a task to matching but untapped information capabilities from other tasks
"Move tasks" moves one or more tasks from one segment to another, possibly also adding goals achieved by the moved tasks to the target segment

section.para: Complex commands are defined in terms of other commands that are executed completely or not at all. Most commands are reversible and can be undone and redone up and until some planner takes an action that would conflict with the undoing or redoing (for example, anyone removing a task prevents a planner from undoing a change he/she recently did to one of its attributes).

The execution of each command is journaled for replay should the server be interrupted and restarted. It is also recorded and listed in the activities tab in the collaboration panel. Channels makes sure that only one command is being executed on an IS plan at a time, no matter how many planners are working on a plan.

glossdef.para: An agent is a person or system who can be assigned tasks in an information sharing plan based on its profile.

A stand in for agents that need not be individually named and profiled. An example would be “Call center employee”. An agent archetype can play multiple roles and have contact info. An agent archetype can be associated with multiple users.
A transmission that could be received by any number of unidentified agents.
A communication channel specifies a means for the transmission of information. A channel is defined by a transmission medium and, where appropriate, an endpoint.
A channel endpoint specifies where a transmission of information in a given medium is transmitted. An email address, radio channel, or phone number are examples of endpoints.
An element of information is a named component of information. An element of information may be classified and can be accompanied with handling and sourcing data.

An entity in ISP is something that can be referenced by name in the definition of one or more segments, tasks, flows, or entities. Entities are agents, transmission media, events, organizations, phases, places, or roles.
An event in ISP is an anticipated change in the environment of organizations that puts their mission at risk.
A gain is a potential positive outcome for an organization caused by an event.
A goal is the intent by an organization to mitigate a risk to itself or to realize a gain during a phase of an event.
An immediate task starts with an event phase.
An incident is an “outside” event not expected to be caused by a task specified in the Plan.
Actionable data.
An information sharing commitment exists between all agents assigned to a task producing information and all agents assigned to the task consuming it.
An information sharing flow specifies a commitment to share information produced from the execution of a task for use in the execution of another task.

An information sharing plan specifies the procedures that people and systems in roles of responsibility are expected to apply in order to fulfill the missions of their organizations before, during, and/or after certain types of events.
An information sharing procedure for an agent is either a task assigned to the agent or a sharing commitment by the agent.

An issue is a problem with an element of an information sharing plan or with the plan as a whole. Issues can be about validity (incorrect definition), completeness (something missing), or robustness (plan is failure-prone).
The location or geographical area for which a role is assigned to an agent by an organization.
A transmission targeting multiple, identified agents.
An organization is a group of persons and systems assigned roles of responsibility and organized to accomplish a mission.
A user associated with an agent in an information sharing plan.

A phase is time relative to the initiation or termination of an event. The pre-event phase is the time before the initiation of the event; the co-event phase is the time between initiation and termination of an event; and the post-event phase is the time after termination of an event.
A kind of agent for which the identity is to be provided by its association with a user. A placeholder agent may allow single or multiple user associations.
A planner is a person authorized to modify an information sharing plan.
A policy is an authoritative statement by an organization as to what is allowed, mandated, or forbidden (prohibited).
A role names implied responsibilities assigned by organizations to agents.
A risk is a potential negative outcome for an organization caused by an event.

The scope of an information sharing plan is comprised of the events and event phases that are planned for, the organizational goals to be met, the participating organizations, and their participating members.
A segment is a manageable subset of an information sharing plan that should include only the tasks and flows needed to achieve one or more stated goals for one phase of one event.
A task is a purposeful action to be carried out separately or as a team by agents.
A task is assigned to an agent if the agent matches the specifications of who is to execute the task.
A transmission medium is a technological or non-technological means for transmitting information. A transmission medium can support unicast, multicast, or broadcast transmissions.
A transmission targeting a single, identified agent.
